course.subject: ECON
course.name: Microeconomics
course.description: Theory of the firm in a free enterprise system; theory of consumer demand; market structures and resource allocation; selected topics on government regulation. More topics treated in greater depth than ECON 2103. Students with non-local qualifications should seek department’s or school’s approval for enrollment in the course.
course.prerequisites: Grade C/D/E in HKAL Economics OR level 3 or above in HKDSE Economics
course.exclusions: ECON 2103, ECON 3113, ECON 3133, SOSC 1440, a passing grade in AL Business and Economics, grade B or above in HKAL Economics

reviews.author: Sin Q
reviews.comment_content:
由淺入深，開頭個幾課中學課程都有涵蓋，不過會有新concept補充同埋間唔中都會有D地方同中學既教法唔同。例如計算price elasticity of demand既時候，percentage change in quantity demanded既算法係 delta Q除以Q既平均值，不是原本的Q。呢D地方要格外小心。
之後由utility and demand開始已經係新野，比較複雜需要多花時間了解內容既應該output and cost (一堆cost curve 既形態同變化)，同埋monopoly，oligopoly等等。lecture powerpoint有D地方解釋得唔夠完整，如果想明晒就最好睇晒書既內容同多問instructor。
Ch0. Introduction
Ch1. Thinking like economists
Ch2. Specialization and Gain from Trade
Ch3. Demand and Supply
Ch4. Elasticity
Ch5. Efficiency and Equity
Ch6. Government meets Market
Ch8. Utility and Demand
Ch9. Possibilities, Preferences and Choices
Ch10. Organizing Production
Ch11. Output and Costs
Ch12. Perfect Competition
Ch13, Monopoly
Ch15. Strategic Interaction and Oligopoly
Ch17. Externalities
reviews.comment_teaching:
成個sem只係上過第一個tutorial，個個禮拜都話轉做office hour。
Prof. 就幾有耐性。好肯花時間答問題。上堂間唔中做下prs，不過唔計分，又唔take attendance，所以唔上堂都冇人理你，不過最好就唔好走，因為有prof. 講解會易明好多。尤其係後段關於monopoly 同 oligopoly 既課題。
唔會飛書教，重要既地方會講多D，所以都唔錯。不過mid term同 final都會有少少題目要睇埋書先識做，powerpoint 可以整得再好D。
reviews.comment_grading:
第一堂已經講明會盡比a range 同b range，所以應該幾好Grade。不過始終都要落力D讀，呢個course 唔算好易，最緊要concept清。
兩種grading schemes:
1) 5% problem sets
    25% mid-term1
    25% mid-term2
    45% final exam
2) 5% problem sets
    35% the best of the two mid-terms
    60% final exam
用邊種grading scheme視乎你邊種既總分會高D。你最多可以走一次midterm，咁就自動變scheme 2。problem sets 總共8個，每個10至20條不等，你上canvas交白紙都冇人理，有交有分。
My result:
Mid-term1: 92.5/100      mean:86           sd:8
Mid-term2: 100/100       mean:74.7        sd:11.8
Final exam: 89.75/100   mean: 60.29     sd:14.12

A+
reviews.comment_workload:
平時可以話冇workload。做下佢比既問題，溫下書，final 同 mid term 前做做佢比既sample paper 就ok.
Final 一定要做多d準備，基本上你明晒全部concept 同計算部分已經足夠。

reviews.author: NOOB_IN_UST
reviews.title: Choose him if you want to jump out from the Mushroom
reviews.comment_content: To be honest, his lecture notes are quite easy, even though I know little about Microeconomics, you can still understand the lecture notes after putting some time for revision. I strongly recommend borrowing the textbook as all the contents of his lecture notes are exactly the same.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is helpful, but he does not know how to teach. if you use Google to search this professor, in his CV he claimed that he has many years  of experience in teaching, but that does not mean he is skillful in teaching.
Eg: During the last ten minutes of a lecture, he stopped teaching and started to answer one question asked before the class. That is related to Marginal Cost, and then he spent 5-10 minutes explained that with differentiation and limit -.- .  
I know that he was trying to explain the concept, but he just made it much more difficult to understand.

I quoted my friend's speech here:
In the lecture, the professor is teaching 1+1 =2
In  the tutorial, the TA is teaching 2+2=3   
i.e.  You don't know what she is teaching, but the contents are much difficult.
In exam, it looks like calculus
reviews.comment_grading:
At first, I was hoping that my grade won't be bad as the curve may help me, but now they use absolute grading, that means you may consider jump out from the Mushroom and end your miserable life.

Just kidding, but you won't get a good grade.
Just after the mid-term exam, someone asked him directly :
Hey, the mid-term is extremely hard, why you torture us and want us to suffer?
He said : If you get full marks in assignment and 9X in final exam, you can still get A.

-.-
reviews.comment_workload: The work load is little as the assignment is lssued bi-weekly.

reviews.author: ustisfun
reviews.title: Robin is a v nice person... but bad in teaching :(
reviews.comment_content:
Covers part of DSE Econ for the first 7 chapters, and some new concepts for later chapters. Be sure to self-learn the new concepts e.g. oligopoly, monopoly, monopolistic competition... otherwise you'll be miserable in your finals because he doesn't really have time to cover all contents in class.

btw, the thing that struggles the most is everything related to margins, e.g. MSC, MSB, MC, MB... he told us that MSB of producing at x+1 unit is = MSB at producing IN x unit, and that MC cannot be used when the table does not tell us is linear. That makes just us soooo confused
reviews.comment_teaching:
To do Robin some justice, he is a good person: He is willing to answer your questions by person and via mail (usually within a day, very efficient), and is also glad to take in opinions.

However, his teaching is subpar. What he does in lectures is basically reading out the slides. (Robin, if you're seeing this review, please do try to explain more about the fundamental concepts given in the slides first, but not reading out the slides directly...). What is more important is that he should cover more exam-related contents in class because he can't just ask something alien all of a sudden in exams!

The tutor, Astor, is very, very, very disastrous. She's even worse than the professor...
Maybe she's nice in person, I'll never know because of the online mode, but she's horrible when it comes to teaching: she goes through over-simplistic question types from her so-called 'notes' which even high school students could accomplish and is not useful to us (her notes are all DIRECT copy and pastes from lecture notes, which are of no use at all. Why don't I read the lecture slides then?).
Worse still, I can't stand the fact that she spent so much time on unnecessary contents, e.g. how to use camscanner, over-elaborating midterm guidelines page by page... Yes, these information are important, but she needs to know how precious tutorial periods are as there are only less than one hour each week for her to finish a chapter.
reviews.comment_grading:
update: got an A eventually 😭😭😭😭😭😭😭😭😭 robin you finally 懂事了

Absolute grading this year, which sucks tremendously. You need at least 70% to get a B and 85% to get an A! I don't know why i could even be in A range, perhaps I was too angry him and revised everything in contents for finals lmao

problem sets 20% ->19/20
midterm exam 35% ->23/35
final exam 45% ->45/45

Midterm is still difficult, perhaps Robin thinks that we are capable of it, but as a result, the mean is 60. I got 64, which is still far away from the highest score 8X.

I think Robin knows what's going on and decided to grace us with a final of lower difficulty (still hard, but you will know how to do each question if you revise). Otherwise, I'm sure all of my classmates will fuck up and get at most a C.

Tips for you if you got enrolled in his course:
Read every page of lecture slides and revise all of them EVEN IF HE DIDN'T MENTION IT. For instance, he asked about a unitary elastic curve that passes through origin in 2020 midterm. Actually, supply that passes through origin has Es of 1, and this is quite tricky because it appears in lecture slides and many people neglect it, thinking that they already know all about elasticity from DSE.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload isn't heavy, as there are only 5 problem sets that are to be accomplished collaboratively with your classmates every 2 weeks.

Remember to ask Robin constantly about something you don't know. Anything that appears on lecture slides (except those trivia, e.g. economists who discovered some trends) can be tested.

If you got any questions, feel free to comment down below

reviews.author: tungcc
reviews.title: Poor prof
reviews.comment_content: Some topics are similar to dse Econ while some are new eg indifference curve.  One midterm + one final +few Problem Sets (hw)

Prof only reads from ppt and his lessons are extremely boring. His accent is 100% mainland English so some words cannot be pronounced clearly.
Ok for the TA and notes will be given as hardcopies by the TA
reviews.comment_grading: Poor grading. He always says that HKUST won’t give a lot of A range to students so he made the midterm to an extremely challenging one. Most students get super super low scores and low grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Only one PS per week , sometimes even no PS. PS are similar to exam questions but it’s an easier version.

reviews.author: jesuisfatiguée
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1. What is Economics
Chapter 2. The Economic Problem
Chapter 3. Demand and Supply
Chapter 4. Elasticity
Chapter 5. Efficiency and Equity
Chapter 6. Government Action in Markets
Chapter 7. Global Markets in Action
--mid term--
Chapter 9. Possibilities, Preferences, and Choices
Chapter 11. Output and Costs
Chapter 12. Perfect Competition
Chapter 13. Monopoly
Chapter 14. Monopolistic Competition
Chapter 15. Oligopoly

For DSE students, the only new stuff for midterm is PPF and maybe income elasticity and cross elasticity. I thought the midterm would be manageable, but then the time is quite tight and u have to do q very fast. Also, one question was like "According to professor yu..." and you have to answer the exact phrase she mentioned in class (5 marks!!). Lesson learnt from this midterm is that you should copy her lecture slides into your cheatsheet using the exact wording. After the midterm, we have more new stuff, and you may want to spend some time to understand the materials. Make sure u attend her classes (or skip the class and watch the video) and listen to her in-class examples. Her final exam question was exactly the same with what she said in class!! In the final exam, many answers were 爛數 :00 (non integer numbers) and you may want to double check to avoid minor calculation mistakes.

Even if you didn't get a good score in the midterm, you still can get a good grade by doing well in the final! (in my opinion final is much easier than midterm. Many people left the exam hall early)
Add oil and good luck :DD!!!
reviews.comment_teaching: Ok la her English is clear. We have 9am lessons so it might be easy to fall asleep :( If she still uploads the lecture videos, maybe it will be more time efficient to watch it.
reviews.comment_grading:
Scheme 1: 25% HW + 25% Midterm +50% Final
Scheme 2: 25% HW + 75% Final
Best of 5 out of 7 HWs
For homework, you only have to answer most questions right, then you can already get a full mark.

Midterm (out of 100):

Mean: 61.08 | Median: 62.45 | High: 87 | Low: 29.5
Upper Quartile: 70 | Lower Quartile: 52.28

Final (out of 100):

Mean: 57.78 | Median: 58.75 | High: 92 | Low: 20
Upper Quartile: 72 | Lower Quartile: 44

Total score:
Me: 91 Grade: A+
Mean: 69.81 | Median: 70.6 | High: 94 | Low: 41.63
Upper Quartile: 79 | Lower Quartile: 59.66

reviews.author: iloveecon
reviews.title: Chill professor with good explanation of concepts
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 0: Economists' Ambition
Chapter 1: What is Economics?
Chapter 2: The Economic Problem
Chapter 3: Demand and Supply
Chapter 4: Elasticity
Chapter 5: Efficiency and Equity
Chapter 6: Government Actions in Markets
Chapter 7: Global Markets in Action
Chapter 9: Possibilities, preferences and choice
Chapter 11: Output and Costs
Chapter 12: Perfect competition
Chapter 13: Monopoly
Chapter 15: Oligopoly+ Basic game theory
Chapter 16: Public Choices and Public Goods
Chapter 17: Externalities
reviews.comment_teaching: He is a chill and funny person because he always cracks some jokes during his lectures which I enjoy a lot. Also, he often relates economic concepts to his own experiences like he relates the diminishing marginal utility to his experience in being a soldier in South Korea which makes it more understandable. Moreover, he is willing to stay behind to answer questions for one hour because simply it's his office hour and he also encourages interactions on zoom which often encourages to just shout out to answer questions. I think it will be better to attend his lessons face to face. However, at the second half of the lectures, he had missed around  three lectures due to his stomach problem and he was in hospital then. So later on he spoke a little but fast on the concepts. But it is manageable because he is very responsible that he uploads extra three zoom recording for us to watch so I can rewatch it many times. Moreover, he skipped teaching monopolistic competition but added some new things that other professors may not teach. For example, the Groves-Clarke Mechanism which is very special and interesting. Also, he teaches game theory the best because he is a game theorist and it is good for someone who wants to know more about game theory. So reg his course if you want to know more about game theory and he can definitely tell you more about that.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance: 10%(this is a zoom-class and he requires all of us to open our cameras so as long as you attend all lessons, you will get that 10%)
Assignments: 15%(1st assignment: 138/140, mean: 131.3, high: 140
2nd assignment: 236/245, mean:230.8, high:245
3rd assignment: 120/120, mean:111.1, high:120)
Midterm: 30%(100 minutes, me:153/200, mean: 124.7, high: 174)
Final: 45%(2 hours, all marks are unknown)
Final grade: A+
I think the grading is lenient because he said he would give 25% top an A which it is unusual in ust. For the midterm, it is quite difficult because we are allowed to open book due to having some online exam for some not-in-hk people. It is about the taxi market in Hong Kong with some background information provided so it really tests your understanding. For the final exam, it is also open book because there are still some not-in-hk people. But I would say the final exam is testing your writing speed more than economic thinking because one long question is exactly the same with previous past paper question and the ta has talked about that question during tutorial. Another two long questions are true or false questions with 50 marks each and basically you have to write an essay explaining whether you agree with that statement or not and simply you can just copy the graphs and explanations from the book. The last long question is the standard hw problem question so it is not difficult at all. One reminder for you all is that he won't have MC in his exams because he said that he hates MC and all are long questions. So some who are good at MC should go to other classes.
reviews.comment_workload: very light workload. Only three assignments but each assignments require you to think more about the economic situation which may take you more than few days. But it is manageable because we are allowed to have groups and we have done it together. Also, the TA provides answers before the submission deadline in the tutorial so make sure you attend the tutorials as well.

Very low average and high sd

reviews.comment_workload:
Homework: time-consuming but not hard, the TA is giving marks according to "how much effort you put into the homework" but not really checking every answer. (Her question wordings are very confusing and we sometimes need to discuss for 15 mins to guess what she was talking about)

Final: confusing and hard LQs (5 LQs), it's open book but the book had no use at all. You can complete the questions as long as you can understand her wordings. Take reference from her mid-term exam.

reviews.author: ericsand
reviews.title: Nice professor and good TA
reviews.comment_content:
Chapters covered in mid-term are taught in compulsory part of HKDSE Economics , except for PPF model.

After mid-term, new topics like consumer theory are introduced.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The professor teaches new content at a speed you must be able to catch up with in lectures, then TA will cover the content again in much faster pace in tutorials.

Some accents are unavoidable, but most of the words uttered can be interpreted.
reviews.comment_grading:
No attendance score counted.

For assignments, they are of average difficulty, so getting marks of 50% or above should not be difficult. Graphs are not automatically graded. Assignments can only be submitted once. Beware of all these which may affect your grade.

For midterm, high 82.5, mean 60.5, median 61.9 , standard deviation 12.5. Quite a number of MCQ and around 5 SQ.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is light, only 1 assignment per two weeks roughly. No group project is needed. As multiple attempts are not allowed in assignments, you just have to do it once so maybe this reduces workload of those who pursue perfect marks and want to complete assignments many times to reach full marks.

reviews.author: estelax
reviews.title: A chill class but final is so hard!!
reviews.comment_content:
Part 1: Introduction
- Problem set 1 covers Chapter 1-2 (What is economics and Specialization and Trade)
- Quiz 0 (free trial)

Part 2: How markets work
- Problem set 2 covers Chapter 3-4 (Demand and Supply and Elasticity)
- Quiz 1
- Problem set 3 covers Chapter 5-6 (Efficiency and Government meets Market)
- Quiz 2

Part 3: Households’ choices
- Problem set 4 covers Chapter 8-9 (Utility and Demand and Possibilities Preferences and Choices)
- Quiz 3

Part 4: Firms and Markets
- Problem set 5 covers Chapter 10-11 (Organizing Production and Output and Costs
- Quiz 4
- Problem set 6 covers Chapter 12-13 (Perfect Competiton and Monopoly
- Quiz 5

Part 5: Market failure
- Problem set 7 covers Chapter 15 (Strategic Interaction and Oligopoly)
- Final exam

Chapter 16 and 17 were expected to be taught but she did not have enough time for teaching

Most of the concepts are learnt in dse econ but some of them are new and more complicated but still manageable (I would suggest watching youtube videos for chapters that you don't understand)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ding Fei is nice and doesn't talk with an accent or monotone, so it is easy to listen. She likes to ask questions although there will be dead air sometimes. However, she will explain one simple concept in different ways during lectures and take up to around 20 minutes. So don't expect final is as easy as lecture materials ==

Emily sometimes makes things too complicated and usually overrun her tutorials. She is willing to reply to emails, so you can ask her for an explanation for quizzes or problem sets.
reviews.comment_grading:
Scheme 1
6 out of 7 Problem Sets  @ 1.5% each 9%
Quizzes (8% each) All five: 40%
Final Exam (cumulative) 51%

Scheme 2
6 out of 7 Problem Sets  @ 1.5% each 9%
Quizzes (8% each) Best three: 24%
Final Exam (cumulative) 67%

The grading scheme is good as she will use the one that gives you higher marks to give you the final grade but the final exam was so hard that it was totally different from quizzes and problem set
Quiz 1: 18/20
Quiz 2: 19/20
Quiz 3: 14/20
Quiz 4: 18/20
Quiz 5: 18/20
Final: 48.6/120 (AVG: 52.1 Median: 48.8 SD:19.8 highest: 119.7)
Final grade: B
I would say it is a decent grading even I mess up final a bit (TMI: I got 5 in dse econ)
Final had two parts: short answers and long questions
MCQs worth 3 marks each and you can choose more than one option. You can have partial credits but for additional wrong answers, 1 mark will be deducted.
Long questions were a disaster. The first question was about demand and supply+ elasticity and most of the questions were computational questions. The second question was about oligopoly and it was also computational questions lol. Very unfriendly to those who are bad in calculations (like me) ==
The third question (30 marks) was about consumption choice (need to draw diagram and make assumption)
TA said this question is hard so students didn't do well
I didn't draw a diagram because idk how to do but I explained my logic in words and get around 10 marks  

TLDR: everything is fine except final
reviews.comment_workload:
It is a zoom class and has no attendance requirement for lectures.  You can watch zoom recordings on canvas anyways. But make sure you attend some of the tutorials as quizzes are held in the last 25 minutes of the tutorial.

For the problem sets, just submit them on canvas on time (even blank paper is fine) and you will get full marks for problem sets (9% of your final grade)

Quizzes are all 20 MCQ on canvas as others had mentioned, you cannot go back once you move on to the next question and they are pretty easy so the mean is high, so be careful when you do the quiz.

She allows 1 double-sided paper cheat sheet for final, but it was so hard so make sure you studied.

reviews.author: cancan
reviews.title: AVOID AT ALL COSTS IF YOU WANT TO SAVE YOUR CGA!!!!!
reviews.comment_content: The content is mostly the same as HKDSE Economics, which might be a bit hard for those who had not taken Economics in their high school before as they may have to spend quite some time to understand the concepts. Involves a bit of Maths but not very difficult as long as you know how the diagrams work.
reviews.comment_teaching:
TL; DR: Skip the lectures if you're good in Econ but read the lecture notes in detail. Recommend you to choose another professor and rearrange your timetable.

If your Economics background is quite good then don't bother attending the lectures. Won't miss out on much even though you had missed the lectures since his notes have already included the points you need to know.

The pace of teaching is a bit slow since he may talk about some slides which we don't have to know (unless you're going to major in Economics) in both the middle and at the end of the lecture (which he stated is additional sometimes). Could have really understood the content quicker and easier had he only included additional content at the end and talked about these slides towards the end of the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
TL; DR: Insane midterm and less insane final. Can easily cost you an Air you're not careful and the midterm can crush your confidence and enthusiasm for the course

-The grading is based on cutoff instead of curve-based.
A: 85%+
B:70-85%
C:55-70%
D:50-55%
Pass: Above 50%
He used absolute grading instead of curve grading when he (intentionally) set the midterm to be quite tough. High-achievers should not choose this professor if you want to have high hopes for an A.

-The midterm is 4 LQs which is quite difficult as he included some question types which he had not even talked about. For instance, he sneaked a point that the PES=1 if the supply curve starts from the origin, which I think should be highlighted in the lecture notes when talking about such absolute things.

- In the final, there are 5 SQs (40%, 8% each) and 3 LQs which are in moderate difficulty.

-The mean for the MT is 61 and the standard deviation is 11.76.
The lowest is 22 and the highest is 88

-The mean for the final is 75. The highest is 98 and the lowest is 34. No stats for SD.

-Weighting
MT:35%
Final:45%
Problem Sets (x5) :15%
Peer Evaluation for PS: 5%
As you can see, the weighting for the MT and Final is quite reasonable. The problem sets are quite easy but the weighting for the peer evaluation might cost you an A if you're not interacting with your groupmates enough.
reviews.comment_workload: Relatively light. Only 5 problem sets throughout the semester which we will have to submit within a week after release. Mostly 3-4 LQs which are not that difficult as you can refer to the lecture notes to understand the question. Would be much easier if you have 1-2 groupmates that can carry you but easy for free-riders to get away since there is little participation needed in the PS ( Only need to check the answer for the PS)

reviews.author: lolllllll
reviews.title: Interesting content and good professor
reviews.comment_content: The content taught mainly revolves around the DSE econ syllabus, so if you get good grades in DSE econ, this course should be easy for you. Although it's similar with the content in DSE, you get to dive deeper into each topics in the scope of microeconomics and there will be a few lectures introducing you to game theory. If you like economics, this course will be a pleasure for you to study.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Lim is very good at teaching and I like his style of teaching very much. He cracks jokes sometimes which makes the lectures fun and engaging. He is a nice guy and a better professor.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is fairly lenient. You basically get what you study for, except if you are really smart or you are really not into it. The curves are pretty high though because it is a course for people who have studied economics before. I guess you can get into A range pretty easily if you get more than 5 in DSE econ.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is pretty low. I had 4 assignments in total for the semester and each assignment has only like several questions. Revision for midterm and final is easy if you got a good professor to teach you the concept well in lectures. Also, no attendance is taken for the lectures and tutorials.

reviews.author: smallpotatojj
reviews.title: Easy concept for student who came across with ECON in DSE
reviews.comment_content: The content is 70% similar to DSE. There are a few new concepts but are easy to tackle. Overall speaking, if you get level 5*or above in DSE before, you will feel the content are dull and you can easily get B+ or above.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Lim Woo Young is a fantastic  professor. He sometimes make jokes during class and his teaching is interesting too. He is a nice person that will answer any question that you raise and he is happy to stay behind class to accommodate you . He is also friendly and will chat with students a bit before class. Be prepare for interactions during class.

His teaching materials are okay. Just the teaching slides are a bit long and the info are scattered, but does not affect much. He teaches according to the slides so skipping lessons won't affect much. You can always revise by the slides. The assignments are basically practice for mid-term and exam. Overall speaking, he is a very good professor and so far my favourite one.
reviews.comment_grading:
There are group assignments so be prepare to find trustworthy group mates. Assignments are easy but take quite a lot of time, around 2-3 hour for one assignment. Usually 1 assignment per 3 weeks/month.

There is only one mid-term and one final. The questions are very similar and sometimes identical to the assignments. So if you know how to nail the assignments you will nail the exams.


Prof. Lim Woo Young is a rather casual professor, attendance accounts for only 5%, does not matter much. Just make the professor remember you by asking questions and you will get the 5%.

I got 5* in DSE, studied around 6 hours for mid-term and 10 hours for final, finished all assignments. Got an A at last.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload isn't very tough. Just assignments spend time to finish but you often get a week or two to finish them, no big problem.

reviews.author: radish
reviews.title: Easy content but average grading
reviews.comment_content: Content generally easy and similar to IB Economics. Would say that there is less analysis/evaluation and more pure memorisation, like boring stuff about MB and MC and ATC and such. Covers general content like demand supply, market failure, market structures etc.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ding Fei (or Fei Ding) teaches clearly with real life situations, for example tweets of news articles she would show on her phone. The lecture slides are average without her explanation.

NO ATTENDANCE TO LECTURES / TUTORIALS.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is somewhere between lenient and difficult. Quizzes with average 75-80% and a final with OK performance rendered a B+. I would say get familiar with the assessment style (asking about technical, graphical stuff etc) early in the course.
reviews.comment_workload: Professor Fei Ding's workload is lightweight but consistent. There are at least 6 quizzes throughout the semester, which require 1-2 hours of revision each, if you're lazy.

reviews.author: skaurp
reviews.comment_content:
Topics Covered:
Demand and Supply

Efficiency and Equity

reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor is very passionate about teaching. His teaching style is very engaging, and he would relate course material to his personal experiences which makes the class interesting. He is willing to answer all my questions after class.
reviews.comment_grading:
5 Homework assignments 20%
1 midterm (100 minutes) 35%
1 final exam (3 hours) 45%

Wooyoung makes the exams paper and homework questions very difficult so that students that understand the topics do well. He always emphasises that the grade will reflect the amount of effort that the student put in. However, econ has always been my favourite subject and I feel that the grade I got definitely did not represent the amount of effort that I put into it.
reviews.comment_workload: There are a few homework assignments that involve group work so make sure you choose a group, where everyone is hardworking. The rest is revising for exams.

reviews.author: Kobe_chh

reviews.comment_content: Basically dse economics, but in a more advance level.  The content is quite easy in the first 50%of the course (until indifference curve) However, the last 50% of the course is a little bit hard( monopoly, oligopoly, perfect competition) and we need to spend more time to digest them.
reviews.comment_teaching: Lim is a humorous and passionate teacher. He is willing to help his students after classes. Sometimes, he would organize some games during lessons to help students to have a better understanding to the content of the course.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework 20%
Midterm 35%
Online final 45%

The grading of homework and midterm is quite obvious and fair. However, Lim does not offer any details about the standard of marking for final and he also did not announce anything about the scores of the exam. So the grading has a grey zone and the fairness of the exam is doubtful.

I got
Hw 1 90/90
Hw 2 260/265
Midterm 185/200
Final ???/200
Grade : A
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is acceptable, except that the homework includes many questions and they are quite challenging.  3-4 people groups can solve it together in an easier way but 1-2 people groups would find it difficult to finish the homework. The content is not really much so that the preparation for final exam is not really hard.

reviews.author: terenceleungch
reviews.comment_content:
Extremely easy for HKDSE students who studied Economics, about 70% of the course content overlaps with the HKDSE syllabus. All the concepts and ideas are simple and straight-forward.
This is a core course for Business School students with prior    experience in economics. The course intends to cover the fundamental concepts and tools that are used in microeconomic    analysis. In this course, economics provides a powerful way of thinking that can help understand many human and social phenomena, and also a wide range of career choices.
reviews.comment_teaching:
the teacher is quite passionate in teaching
she introduces each concept in a clear manner, and sometimes uses videos and mini games in class to illustrate them
quite easy to understand if you pay attention
reviews.comment_grading:
grading is quite good, easy to achieve good grades especially when you have attended the HKDSE with similar contents

my result:
midterm above 0.75 sd
final above 0.75 sd
final grade: B
reviews.comment_workload:
have midterm and final exam
have assignment, about once a month
no essay and reading material
no project and presentation
no attendance is taken, however, PRS will be used and the participation will be contributed to the grade

reviews.author: s101003
reviews.comment_content:
Ch.1 What is Economics
Ch.2 The Economic Problem
Ch.3 Supply and Demand
Ch.4 Elasticity
Ch.5 Efficiency and Equity
Ch.6 Government Actions in Markets
Ch.7 Global Markets in Actions
Ch.8-9 Possibilities, Preferences, and Choices
Ch.11 Output and Costs
Ch.12 Perfect Competition
Ch.13 Monopoly
Ch.15 Oligopoly
Ch.16 Public Goods
Ch.17 Externalities

Topics taught before first mid-term are all covered in the DSE syllabus.
Though topics after first mid-term exam are mostly new things, they are not too difficult.

Tutorials give quick reviews of things taught in lecture with some example questions.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor is very patient. She always stayed behind to answer students' questions.

The lecture ppts are very detailed and clear. Even if you missed any lecture, you can still catch up simply by reading the ppts. Textbook is optional since the lecture ppts are very good.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assessment contains the following:

1) Problem sets (10%)
There are 2 problem sets in total. Answer to the most of the questions can be found on the Internet.

2) Online Quizzes (10%)
10 Quizzes in total. 10 questions each. They are credited by submission. As long as you submit all the quizzes before deadline, no matter how much score you got, you'll still get a full mark for this category.

3) Mid-term Exams (20%+20% OR 30%)
2 Mid-term exams in total. Topics covered in each exam were very few. Both are quite easy.
- 35 MCQ (70%), 2 LQ (30%)
- 1st Mid-term: Mean 85.3, S.D. 8.6
- 2nd Mid-Term: Mean 80.7 S.D. 9.4

4) Final Exam (40% OR 50%)
Difficulty is easier than DSE Econ.
- Mean: 83.8 S.D.: 11.95

~93-95% A-
~95-98% A
~98-100% A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is not heavy.

Each problem set can be completed in 1-2 hours.
Each Online Quiz can be done in around 10 minutes.

reviews.author: rororooo
reviews.comment_content: Based on DSE syllabus with some additional more complicated concepts. Content is not hard to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching: No attendance required. She reads the powerpoint. Yet her powerpoints are not as clearly presented as ZhangWenWen's, she likes to hide some parts and only release it right before the midterm/finals. A tiny part seems to be contradictory to what we have learnt in secondary and there tends to be occasional mistakes in powerpoints.
reviews.comment_grading:
2 midterms only multiple choice and one final exam. It is quite challenging, the mean for the first midterm is 87, while the mode is around 95? But the final exam is MUCH HARDER than the midterm exams and practices.
Even if i get above mean for everything, both midterms above 90% I still only got B range.
reviews.comment_workload: Very Light. Just submit all 8 problem sets on time on canvas then it is fine.

reviews.author: hbyoon97
reviews.title: An introductory class to Microeconomics
reviews.comment_content:
Similar to Microecomics in IB. Only a few topics are more complex. Some things are taught different than in higschool (IB), so you will have to get rid of your IB habbits.

Theory of the firm in a free enterprise system; theory of consumer demand; market structures and resource allocation; selected topics on government regulation. More topics treated in greater depth than ECON 2103. Students with non-local qualifications should seek department’s or school’s approval for enrollment in the course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
OK.
All the content can be found on powerpoint slides, so you don't have to attend the lectures. However, I recommend going to lecture for professors explanatino, very clear.
reviews.comment_grading:
It is quite hardcore. Two MCQ midterms (only the better one counts, fortunately) and a final - MCQ plus open questions. The mean on midterms is really high - they are doable for 100%.
However the final was SUPER SUPER hard and really tricky. Wasn't prepared for that. I recommend that you study very hard for the finals as some problems you see will not something you learn before, so must be able to apply knwoledge into problems.

No quizzes, no attendence.

However, again, I recommend that you go to class everyday to ensure that you understand the concepts in the professor's ways so that when you take the exams, professors will know that you have attended the lessons and you are ready with the material.
reviews.comment_workload: Moderate. The course is not hard, there are no quizzes, you don't have to pay attention on every lesson. If you put in the time and effort, the material should not be difficult and you will manage to score well.

reviews.author: Dreamscometrue
reviews.comment_content:
Basic Microeconomics concepts.

Scarcity
Demand and Supply
Market intervension
Global market
Utility and indifference curves analysis
Output and costs
Market structure
Basic game theory
Externality
Public goods

Content before midterm is mainly DSE stuff, if you can excel in the public exam, you should have no problem.

Post midterm knowledge will be new to local students, it is better to study harder by reading the powerpoint and textbooks.

Content taught by Professor Zhang is simpler and fewer than another professor.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Zhang definitely has a good voice which makes the lecture not so boring. Her teaching is based on the slides and the books, if you can understand the materials fully, there is not a great need to attend lectures.

In the lectures, she will project a printed slides and will keep making notes on it. Although most of them will not be tested in exam, you can get some extra knowledge. Her presentation is clear with identifiable accent, but with few value-added from the textbook. Breaks will be allowed in all lecture time, good for us to refresh our minds. She will also play different interesting videos during breaktime. Games related to microeconomics will be played in lectures, quite a good idea.

One point to note: never talk in her lectures, she will be annoyed and stop immediately if the lecture room is noisy.

Anyway there were just around half of the class attending each time.
reviews.comment_grading:
Should be quite good, but final exam marks are not released

Around 1 sd to score an A range
reviews.comment_workload:
Few workload.

10 canvas quizzes, hand in = getting marks
2 problem sets (will be marked and graded by TAs, questions are from the book)
1 mid-term (not difficult, 20 MCQs + 1SQ + 1 short essay, questions copied from the internet)
1 Final (much more difficult, 25 MCQs+4 SQs + 1 short essay, but again, questions are copied from the internet)

No attendance, no participation, no projects :)

reviews.author: xyxy
reviews.title: PLEASE change the professor
reviews.comment_content: Her powerpoint is easy to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching: Her accent is bit difficult to understand.
reviews.comment_grading:
Her final exam was a disaster, even though you studied well for it. The exam didn't focus on her powerpoints, and I don't know what happened with her exam. Although she provided us with sample papers, they were totally useless as the format and types of questions were extremely different.
Her quizzes were easy, and I almost got a full score every time.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Robin isnt that bad, the comment about him is a bit over. The mid term exam is extremely hard and i was around median. The final exam is much easier than the mid term and i got UQ. FInally i got a A-.
He will provide zoom recording and take attendance by in class quizzes. You have to submit 5 out of 6 to get full attendance. The quizzes are counted base on attendance instead of correctness.

You dont have to attend the tutorial as it is a bit useless personally.
reviews.comment_grading:
In-class Quizzes 5%
There are 6 in-class quizzes; only 5 of them will be counted.
We will use IPRS (link) to conduct the quizzes. The quiz time will not be announced in advance.
Students can only attend quizzes of their own sessions.
The score will be counted upon submission, regardless of whether the answer is correct.
Problem Sets 20%
There are 5 problem sets; they will be posted every two weeks.
Work in groups with 3 or 4 people in the same session;
Each PS will account for 3%; the remaining 5% will be peer evaluation score.
Midterm Exam 30%
Final Exam 45%
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is manageable but make sure you go find your groupmate as soon as possible. It is also a good way to find your study partner and make friends!

shit grading.

n-class Quizzes 5%

Students can only attend quizzes of their own sessions.

reviews.author: Colourful_black
reviews.title: Professor Robin <3
reviews.comment_content:
What you expect in Microeconomics showed up. Such as basic demand, supply, PPF,  elasticity and different types of market.

You will only need the PowerPoint and forget about the book. The PowerPoint contains content from the book and simplified it.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I had a really great time with Prof. Robin. I sometime fall asleep but it doesn't mean that his class is not interesting. It is because I learnt some of the ideas before. I love his math stuff even thought some classmates don't like it. I wish he could teach more math but it is an introdution course at the end of the day so he cannot. He is always willing to answer my stupid questions after class and I wish I could attend his class in the future.

The TA is nice but just skip her tutorial la. Prof. Robin taught enough knowledge for me to smash the test(s) or exam(s).
reviews.comment_grading:
He told us that it is absolute grading and tell us the cutoff before the final exam. He didn't tell me the cutoff at the end.

Forgot all of my scores. Around 8x in mid-term and unknown final.
Problem set should be around 9x, close to full mark anyway.
Participation: six IPRS attendance checking in total, only five will be counted.

Final letter grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
1 easy problem set fortnight. Not diffcult at all. He could increase the difficulties if he wants to differentiate students' ability but don't include more questions. haha

Very light workload.
Past papers are provided by Prof. Robin so there's no need to buy source.

lenient grading with no attendance needed.
Studied the day before the examination.
Final grade:A

reviews.author: bianca Chen
reviews.title: Fair grade and helpful TA!
reviews.comment_content:
There's supposed to be the monopoly part in our DSE but the elective part was being cancelled. Therefore, I personally think that those topics were difficult to catch up.

The following topics need some time to understand and practice:
Consumer theory
Oligopoly
Monopoly
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof Yu would provide real life examples when she's going to explain some theories. Besides, she is willing to answer your questions after classes. However, lectures were a bit boring I would say.

Nevertheless, the TA (Jeremy) will provide some practical questions during his tutorial sessions (which is quite similar to our final exam). Detailed explanation will be given if you ask him any questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fair I would say.

Best 5 of 7 homework assignments      25%
1 midterm exam    0% or 25%
1 final exam    50% or 75%

Midterm will not be counted if you did much more better on the final exam. Therefore, don't lose hope even if you got unsatisfactory results during the midterm exam!

Final examination is cumulative.
reviews.comment_workload:
There will be one assignment in every one to two weeks.
No quizzes were to be conducted throughout this course.

reviews.author: Oab
reviews.title: Keep improving
reviews.comment_content:
1. Comparative Advantages + PPF (first half DSE stuff) (Difficulty: 2)
2. The Economic Problem
3. Demand and Supply (DSE stuff) (Difficulty: 1)
4. Elasticity (first half DSE stuff) (Difficulty: 1)
5. Efficiency and Equity (DSE stuff) (Difficulty: 1)
6. Government Actions in Markets (first half DSE stuff) (Difficulty: 2)
7. Utility and Demand (All new) (Difficulty: 5)
8. ***Possibilities, Preferences, and Choices*** (All new) (The most challenging part) (He examines this part in practice midterm, actual midterm, practice final, and actual final, so make sure you attend this lecture and grasp the concepts) (Difficulty: 9)
9. Output and Costs (More than DSE stuff, elaborate the relation between output [TP, AP, MP] and cost [TC, AC, MC]) (Difficulty: 3)
10. Perfect Competition (Mostly new) (Difficulty: 4)
11. Monopoly (Mostly new) (Difficulty: 4)
12. Monopolistic Competition (Mostly new) (Difficulty: 6)
13. Oligopoly + Game theory (Mostly new) (Difficulty: 7)
14. Externalities (DSE stuff) (Difficulty: 1)
15. Markets for Factors of Production (Mostly new) (Difficulty: 2)
16. Economic inequality (first half DSE stuff) (Difficulty: 1)

His PowerPoint slides should be from the book.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I thought I was done after reading past comments.
I feel he is willing to improve, as he tried to use more examples and rely less on his PowerPoint slides. (But yes, he is still reading slides.)
And he is pretty fluent compared with some new lecturers.
So I decided to attend his lectures every time.
But he likes explaining Mathematics behind Economics.
TA sucks, and no one attends tutorials.
There were four people, including me, the last time I attended it, which was when I wanted to leave during the tutorial.
TA notes are quite concrete; reading them for 30 minutes is better than attending the one-hour tutorial, so I skipped the tutorial every time.
reviews.comment_grading:
Problem set and peer evaluation: full (as long as you hand in them)
Midterm: 86/100
Final: 92/100
Grade: A+

Better than I expected.
I am 5** in DSE Economics, but it does not help a lot.

Revision tips:
1. Do a mock exam to manage your time better (He will give out all past examinations before midterm and final, as well as a practice paper)
2. Read the problem set paper and answer before the examination - they are more or less the same as the actual paper.

* Don't care about TA practice questions; they are entirely different from the actual paper.
* If you like Mathematics, stay. If you don't like it, run.

He should be more lenient this time.
He likes to ask a question related to Mathematics rather than Economics concepts.
So there is no need to memorise; understanding the concepts is enough.
I did not revise a lot; following the revision tips should be enough to get an A-range.
reviews.comment_workload:
Quite light.
There are five problem sets.
If you don't want to work for it, you can just answer a few sentences for each question in problem sets.
No matter how many marks you get in the problem sets, as long as you hand in all problem sets, you can still get a full mark for the problem sets grade.

reviews.author: Echoings
reviews.title: I love Tang Rui and you will too
reviews.comment_content:
High school economics, basically the IB syllabus + one unit not taught in IB
Very easy and doesn't take any effort to prepare, especially if you're in 2113 which is supposed to be for students with Econ experience
reviews.comment_teaching:
Hard to understand his English pronunciation and kind of boring, but I can tell he takes his teaching seriously

I guess if you want to pay attention and learn in class he might not be the best choice? lmao
reviews.comment_grading:
Loose grading

* Assignments - He'll give you 4/4 as long as you do every question
* Midterm / Finals - Simple and generally easy questions, shouldn't be a problem at all
* Attendance - Doesn't take attendance!

Overall - I didn't study for anything at all and I got 6 in Econ HL, and I still managed to get a B, so that should give you an idea of the difficulty
reviews.comment_workload:
Assignments every 1-2 weeks, done in groups
One midterm and one final, but both are very easy (somehow I thought the midterm was more difficult lol)

She did not manage her teaching progress well and she has to teach extremely fast before midterm and final to chase the progress. However, she is teaching much better after midterm. Professor Xie is a nice person and very willing to answer your questions after lesson.

reviews.author: chaechae_1
reviews.title: Very Hard if you have not studied DSE Econ before
reviews.comment_content:
Course Outline
Part I. Introduction
1. What is Economics Chapter
Chapter 2. The Economic Problem
Part II. How Markets Work
Chapter 3. Demand and Supply
Chapter 4. Elasticity
Chapter 5. Efficiency and Equity
Chapter 6. Government Action in Markets Chapter 7. Global Markets in Action

Chapter 12. Perfect Competition Chapter
13. Monopoly

reviews.comment_teaching: Her teaching is okay but her voice is so damn soft and boring. I almost skipped all of her classes and watched playback later for 2x speed. I have no idea why some of those can really withstand the whole morning lesson.
reviews.comment_grading: OK la, I got an overall B grade. I fucked up my midterm and got nearly the lowest, but luckily she offered two schemes thats allows students to have an overall higher score and my midterm score was then excluded (others have mentioned the details below), my final exam was slightly above median and I totally didn’t expect that, so I would consider it as a good grade course :)
reviews.comment_workload: Fair, one assignment twice a week and you will almost get full marks if you really paid effort to finish it. However, for senior entry students like me, who only studied microeconomics for only one and a half month and without DSE background and did not have a credit transfer on this course, compared to those who have studied 3 years of economics, its absolutely a disaster to revise and learn the Econ stuffs, as the professor will assume you to have learnt most concepts and actually you didn’t. You may read through other comments and find others saying this course is just like a review of what they have learnt and have a minimal workload, but I better recommend you to put very high effort and time in reviewing the notes before lesson and revise it, otherwise you will definitely gonna fail the course! Frankly speaking, for those without DSE and IB Econ background,  just like those who didn’t take DSE BAFS to study Acct2010, BE PREPARED AND SUFFER!

reviews.author: cwsn
reviews.comment_content:
Please refer to others for details.
Around 60-70% are taught in DSE. However, for DSE students, his marking scheme is quite different from the DSE marking scheme so it is hard for me to score all the points. So just pay attention to how he marks the hw.
reviews.comment_teaching: His lectures are quite boring I would say and he mostly just read out the lecture slides.
reviews.comment_grading:
Nots sure if he is using absolute grading or curve grading .
I got almost full mark for every assignment and 0.8 sd above mean for both midterm and final but just got a B.
reviews.comment_workload:
Light workload.
Only a 3-questions assignment once a week, finished in form of group of four.

reviews.title: Best Professor in my first semester
reviews.comment_content:
Before the mid-term, the content is basically covered by DSE except for one concept, which is the PPF, but trusts me, not so difficult if you attend the lesson.
After the mid-term, a lot of new concepts will be taught, or old concepts in DSE will be further explored. Some of them are quite challenging, but Professor Gong will tell us which parts will not be tested, so make sure to attend ALL lectures.
The list of chapters can be found in other reviews, so I'm gonna skip that part.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Good teaching, not the best, but I can see Robin trying his best to make the lecture lively. In most cases, Robin relies on his slides, but it is ok because the powerpoints are well-designed, clearly structured, and detailed, just revising by reading the PPT and doing some past paper will get you an A.

Besides, he is helpful and patient. If you ask him questions after the lecture, he is more than willing to answer them for you with the most detailed explanation. Also, one thing that I appreciate so much is that he replies to emails efficiently,

At last, some may think his accent is weird but I found that his accent is better than most professors.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance: 5%
Assignment: 20% (5% for peer evaluation)
Mid-term: 30%
Final: 45%

MT: 96/100
Mean:73/100   
SD:14
Highest: 96/100                       

Final: 94/100
Mean: 68.5
SD: 1X
Highest: 97/100

Attendance is constituted by 6 pop-up in-class quizzes, aim to make sure you guys are attending lessons, and only 5 of them will be counted (it's kinda useless as the code could be easily got if you have friends, but I am sure Robin knows this and he is ok with it, he is just so good)  

There are, in total 5 assignments, done by a group of 3-4. To be honest, the workload is super light if you got responsible teammates, but luckily it only requires an hour for one person to finish everything. 5% is peer evaluation, which depends on the relationship of your team, but in most cases, those are free points.

Mid-term and Final are more the less the same in terms of format, and Robin will upload past papers on Canvas, make sure you finish all of them, and you will be fine.

Overall, I kinda like his grading as it is reasonable and easy to get A range.
reviews.comment_workload:
Affordable

Each assignment takes less than an hour to finish by yourself, so it's fine. But make sure you know how to draw graphs on Google Documents, which is very important.

There are, in total, 22 chapters, each has 30-50 pages, and it takes 15-30 mins to finish one.

Overall, it is a good course.

reviews.author: Chainrule C.
reviews.title: Requires a lot of comprehension
reviews.comment_content:
repetitive, others have uploaded
Oh, I do have a very useful tip for you:
Pay full attention in class,
coz, there may be ques like: Prof. Yu has mentioned in the class, the most important application of perfect competitive market is.... Trust me, you will literally roar at the exam sheet if you do not know her exam style :((
reviews.comment_teaching:
If you have learnt econ before, you would find it much more like a review. Unfortunately, I did not pay attention to my teacher back to high school.
Teaching is not so appealing or interesting, and it really needs to pay full attention and be absorbed in the class; otherwise, you would find you lose your train of thought very quickly.
Overall, teaching is fine for reviewing, but adsolutely not for those with lame base or for simply exams. If you wanna score high in exams, just take some exercise on your own.
reviews.comment_grading:
I got A-
hw full
mt 73/100 upper Q:70
final 78/100 upper Q:
No attendance
fair grading, though it requires hard work. I feel like I am pretty lucky, coz I only studied for a night before the exam, and I just reviewed the calculation part and content after mt, though it's cumulative. However, do not learn me, but plz learn from my lesson, dont wait till the last minute (I didnot sleep the night before final).
reviews.comment_workload:
Fair
choose best 5 hw

reviews.author: trash in ust
reviews.comment_content: The first few chapter is DSE things, such as PPF, demand and supply and efficiency. It will only spend you little time to pick up. After that, there are some new topic that didn't mention in DSE such as utility and budget line, but it is not too difficult to understand. In the later chapter is about perfect competition, monopoly and oligopoly. These topics have been mentioned in DSE, but in this course, it will go deeper than DSE level and is much difficult than DSE level. Nearly all of them are conceptual knowledge and can not learn by rote. Apart from that, the course need to do some basic calculation, but its only very very easy things, such as linear equation. No need to worry if you are not good at math.
reviews.comment_teaching: She will go though all the detail in the lecture notes. She will also use real life example to explain the topic. Apart from that, she is willing to answers question. However, for me , I think the lecture is quite boring, so I skipped all the lecture after add-drop period.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good grading and there are 2 grading systems.
Scheme 1: 9% HW, All 5 quizzes total 40%, Final 51%
Scheme 2: 9% HW, Best 3 quizzes total 30%, Final 61%
-The marks of hw is base on submission, thats mean you can submit a blank document than get full marks.
-There are 5 online quizzes in total, each include 20 mc. Scheme 2 will be used if you miss the quiz. The final exam is hard af, so you better not missing any quiz.

My grade:
-Quiz: 18/20, 19/20, 15/20, 19/20, 16/20
-Final: 81.5/120, Mean 55.75
Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload: Nearly no workload. HW marks is base on submission. You don't need to finish the HW, you just need to press a button to hand in a blank document to get full marks. There is quiz every 2weeks, you only need to spend some time to do revision.

reviews.author: Crockett
reviews.title: Intro microeconomics
reviews.comment_content:
Copy from others:
Ch. 1: What is Economics?
Ch. 2: The Economic Problem
Ch. 3: Demand and Supply
Ch. 4: Elasticity
Ch. 5: Efficiency and Equity
Ch. 6, 7: Government Actions in Markets
Ch. 8: Utility and Demand
Ch. 9: Possibilities, Preferences, and Choices
Ch. 10, 11: Output and Costs
Ch. 12: Perfect Competition
Ch. 13: Monopoly
Ch. 14: Monopolistic Competition
Ch. 15: Oligopoly
Ch. 17: Externalities
Ch. 18: Markets for Factors of Production
Ch. 19: Economic inequality
Some contents are dse stuff, since it is just an introductory course, the economic concepts are not hard to grasp. Also, Robin did not teach public goods this semester. He told me that he was not good at teaching that haha.
reviews.comment_teaching:
90% of the time he just read through the PowerPoint of lecture notes. Sometimes if there are some concepts need to be clarify, he will spend more time elaborating them, such as the intuition of P>MR in monopoly. However, he may get overzealous in doing that and start talking the maths behind the intuition. As someone who like Econ, it’s ok but I think others will be confused by that.

One big props for Robin is that he is always willing to answer your question whether it’s in person after class or through emails. He also answers question that related to economics but not within the syllabus. So I think he is a very passionate economics teacher.

Be aware that the way he speaks in monotonic tone will drive you asleep, and sometimes his pronunciation of some wordings is hard to understand.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading scheme:
In class quizzes(for attendance taking) 5%
Problem sets:  20%
Mid-term:  30%
Final exam: 45%

Mid-term statistic:
Mean: 71.4/100
Highest: 96/100
Final statistics:
Mean: 68.5
Highest: 97

I did not good in mid-term 81/100, and I think getting A-range is hard considering the mid-term. But I did better in final, 9x/100 and final grade is an unexpected A+. So I think the grade is good.
reviews.comment_workload:
5 problem sets work in group. Distributed once a fortnight.
The problems are not difficult that even if you encounter free riders in your group, you can manage to finish the problems by yourself within an hour.

reviews.author: Hexadecimal
reviews.comment_content:
Content :
1. What is economics
2. Specialization and trade
3. Demand and supply
4. Elasticity
5. Efficiency and equity
6. Government intervention
7. Utility and demand
8. Possibilities, preferences and choices
9. Organizing production
10. Output and costs
11. Perfect competition
12. Monopoly
13. Strategic interaction of duopoly

Chapters 1-6 are all DSE content whereas chapters 7-13 are new, since a lot of content is being jammed into a couple of months of teaching it is best that you review the concepts regularly or even to apply them to real life. Getting familiar with the concepts through regular application allowed me to take the exam without any revision the prior week (was busy studying for acct :/)
reviews.comment_teaching: Her teaching is pretty decent as she entertains most questions and encourages interaction (asking questions, using the iPRS system etc) but that sometimes results in dead air. Most of the content is highly understandable. Oh yeah she also doesn't take attendance
reviews.comment_grading:
Two grading schemes
Scheme 1 :
6 out of 7 Problem Sets  @ 1.5% each ==> 9%
All 5 quizzes @ 8% each ==> 40%
Final exam 51%

Scheme 2 :
6 out of 7 Problem Sets  @ 1.5% each ==> 9%
Best 3 quizzes @ 10% each ==> 30%
Final exam 61%

Final exam statistics :
Full marks : 120
Mean : 55.75
Median : 51.5
Highest score : 102
Lowest score : 28.5
Upper quartile : 64.5
Lower quartile : 46

The exam is so difficult that the mean is below 50% lmao

My results :
Best 3 Quizzes : 18/20, 18/20, 19/20
Final exam : 87.5/120
Grade : A

Note : I feel like the exam is made to make BBA Econ/ BSc ECOF majors ask themself if they really want to study economics
reviews.comment_workload: Light, very light. There is a problem set every two chapters which contributes to 9% of your grade. Full marks are given as long as you submit something. DO NOT DO NOT DO NOT think of the problem set as exam practice. Think of it as an opportunity to familiarize yourself with the concepts, because trust me- the exam is very very different.

reviews.author: =B=
reviews.title: The best profesor I've encountered

Very usefu ppt, all the stuff asked in exams are from the ppt, so you only need to revise them, don't need any extra materials.

I heard that his lessons are boring, but I think it's interesting, and he has done he's best to make the lectures as interesting as possible, which I highly appreciate that. He's also very friendly and willing to answer our question

The TA is very good at shirking, she can make up thousands of reasons to skip lessons, which impresses me a lot. So just give up on the tutorials, the lectures are already good enough for you.

5/5
A- at last. It's considered satisfactory for me as I only revised the day before exam.

reviews.comment_teaching:
I absolutely loved the way Professor Lim taught in his class. Honestly, it was a little hard to understand his Korean accent in the start, but you usually get used to it. He's an amazing professor and knows how to keep the class engaging and interesting. I usually had to take classes at 6:30am in the morning (time zone difference) but I never felt sleepy during his lectures!

The TA was also really nice (Liu Ying). She clarified doubts and concepts very well during her tutorials. She discusses the assignment solutions before the deadline, and that is of great help!
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance: 10% (just keep your cameras on if its a zoom class)

Homework assignments: 15%, in my opinion, the assignments were a little challenging but interesting nevertheless. Professor Lim picks out articles from newspapers and asks questions related to microecon related to actual real life events. Much more application based, which is the best!

Midterm: 30%, challenging, same type of questions as the assignment. Super lengthy and hard to finish tho! Mean: 124.5/200

Final Exam: 45%, same as above. Don't know the mean.
reviews.comment_workload:
I would say just the right amount.

You can do the assignment in groups of 3/4, so the workload is shared. Would take a lot of time to do the whole thing yourself though.

the timing of midterm is not enough, and remember SHORT answer questions only require you to give exact answers instead of too many words for explanation.

However, it is sleepy to listen to what she had said, I don't know why may be is because of her voice.

For me, I think she may teach too slow because she always uses up a lot of time to explain something that is easy and for some difficult concepts, I cannot understand with her explantions.

But, generally, the teaching is good.

However, for the TA Jeremy, I think his teaching is at a fast pace which I cannot follow up. If you want to follow his step you have to stop jotting notes in class and watch the zoom recording again to write down the notes.

But, if you send emails to him, he can always reply to you immediately which is great.

reviews.comment_workload:

reviews.author: lmaosiu4
reviews.title: Excellent teaching and interactive lectures, full of fun
reviews.comment_content:
Introductions (Chapter 1 – Chapter 2)
▪ What is Economics?(Chapter 1)
▪ The Economic Problem (Chapter 2)

How Markets Work (Chapter 3 – Chapter 5)
▪ Demand and Supply (Chapter 3)
▪ Elasticity (Chapter 4)
▪ Efficiency and Equity (Chapter 5)
▪ Government Actions in Markets (Chapter 6)
▪ Global Markets in Action (Chapter 7)

Household’s Choices
▪ Consumers’ Behavior (Chapter 9)

Firms and Markets (Chapter 11- Chapter 13, Chapter 15)
▪ Output and Costs (Chapter 11)
▪ Perfect Competition (Chapter 12)
▪ Monopoly (Chapter 13)
▪ Oligopoly (Chapter15)

The content is built up based on DSE microeconomics syllabus. The practical theories are far more complicated than DSE. Extra effort is needed in order to master the application of those theories. So don't assume you can master everything just because you've taken Econ in DSE.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Wenwen is a humorous professor. I'm impressed by her humour. We often have games in her lessons. I never slept in her class lol.

Helpful and nice TA as well. Thx Peter.
reviews.comment_grading:
Scheme (1): Course score with TWO midterms  
Assessment Activities Weighting
Problem Sets 10%
Quizzes 5%
Midterm Exam ((1) and (2)) 20%+20%
Final exam (cumulative) 45%

Scheme (2): Course score with ONE midterm
Assessment Activities Weighting
Problem Sets 10%
Quizzes 5%
Midterm Exam ((1) or (2), the higher one) 30%
Final exam (cumulative) 55%

*Two schemes are compared, a higher overall score under either of the 2 schemes will be counted towards the final grading.

*Problems sets and quizzes are counted on a submission basis. You'll score full when you submit on time, even if you get zeroes.

My grades:
Full credits for quizzes and problem sets
Mid term 1 (84/100) (Mean:79.79, Median: 82; SD: 9.7)
Mid term 2 (93.5/100) (Mean: 89; SD: 9.3)
Final (94/100) (Mean: 73.7)

Final grade: A
I guess the grading is quite fair.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is not that heavy.

reviews.author: Smashgod
reviews.title: The definition of 'chill', but study very hard for the final exam
reviews.comment_content:
1. What is economics
2. Specialization and Trade
3. Demand and Supply
4. Elasticity
5. Efficiency
6. Government meets Market
8. Utility and Demand
9. Possibilities Preferences and Choices
10. Organizing Production
11. Output and Costs
12. Perfect Competiton
13. Monopoly
15. Strategic Interaction and Oligopoly

Ch. 7 and 14 are not taught. Ch. 16 and 17 were expected to be covered if there was time but we didn't have enough.

Most of the content is basically covered in the high school Economics already with slight variations. Ch.8, 9, and 15 have the most number of new concepts, and Ch. 12-13 have the most extensions. Since only students who have taken Economics will take ECON2113, it is a pretty simple course. Just be sure to expect little differences in question types, concepts, and other items. There are interesting discussion topics and scenarios.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ms. Ding's lessons are very chill. She can talk about a topic for 10-20 minutes without key points (what locals will call 'blowing water'). It is hard to know where the main point is when she does that. If you decide to not pay attention because you already know Economics, it is also not a good choice because you may miss some useful tips, so there is a dilemma.

There is a tutorial every week for one day that teaches the computational skills but the TA, Ms. Chen Kwan, tends to overcomplicate things and the skills are not useful in practice. She usually overruns as well.
reviews.comment_grading:
Pretty disappointed at the large proportion the final exam takes up given the formidable difficulty. Very risky class to take even if you only want a decent grade. You may be fine if you are an elite.
There are 5 online MC quizzes with 20 questions per quiz (actually 6 in total but the first one is not counted towards the final score). Each is 8%. Open-book but there is a very bad system that you must make a choice before proceeding to the next question. You cannot return to the previous question after confirming your answer as well.
There are 7 Problem sets in total and the 6 with the highest scores will be counted towards the final score. You already get full marks if you finish them and submit them on time. They take up 9% of the grand total.
The final exam is NOTHING LIKE the usual questions! Extremely complicated and advanced compared to the exercises and assignments. Even if you do well in usual quizzes, be prepared for incredibly hard computational questions. Here are the statistics:
Average 52.1/120
Median 48.8/120
STDEV 19.8
As you can see, the mean and median are both under 50% of the score. The lowest score is 13/120.
Ms. Ding has a fair policy of calculating our final score by shifting more of the weight to the exam or the quizzes according to the method that gives students the higher score out of the two. Details can be found on page 3 in the attached document.
reviews.comment_workload:
Pretty light! There is enough time for the assignments.
Quizzes happen biweekly in tutorials but that's also why the progress is a little slow. Something very disappointing is that our final tutorial and quiz had to take place during the study break, one day before my first final exam.

reviews.author: wilsonng
reviews.comment_content: Quite easy and interesting
reviews.comment_teaching:
He is helpful, but he does not know how to teach. if you use Google to search this professor, in his CV he claimed that he has many years  of experience in teaching, but that does not mean he is skillful in teaching.
Eg: During the last ten minutes of a lecture, he stopped teaching and started to answer one question asked before the class. That is related to Marginal Cost, and then he spent 5-10 minutes explained that with differentiation and limit -.- .  
I know that he was trying to explain the concept, but he just made it much more difficult to understand.

I quoted my friend's speech here:
In the lecture, the professor is teaching 1+1 =2
In  the tutorial, the TA is teaching 2+2=3   
i.e.  You don't know what she is teaching, but the contents are much difficult.
In exam, it looks like calculus

Good content if you are interested in Economics. Most content are already introduced in HKDSE, though you will encounter some new stuffs since ch.6 and after the midterm. This course serves a good introduction to microeconomics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Li's teaching is not very good. Her teaching is boring. But she is enthusiastic in teaching. Note that she taught two additional chapters (Ch.7 & 17) comparing with another instructor from another section (L4), but these chapters are also included in exams. She is nice too.

The TA, Mr Tsui (Peter) is better. He explains concepts clearly. Although he looks cool, he is nice. I remember the numbers of participants in his tutorials are more than the usual lectures. Tutorials are not held every week. Nevertheless, his voice is a bit of monotone, and he only released his notes after the whole tutorial, and he won't release the recording of the tutorial, that's a bit inconvenient.

reviews.comment_teaching:
YU, Yan is pretty good and try to illustrate the concepts using different examples, tho she have a bit of accent but personally I think its better than majority of ust prof so im fine with it.
She also digs more deeply into the mathematics part of economics, so for those who hates maths, you should look for another prof, almost half of her final is based on maths.
the TA To, Jeremy is also good, he will explain some concepts that aren't explained much in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class participation 5%
Best 5 out of 7 homework assignments 20%
mid term exam 25%
group video project 15%
final exam 35%

class participation is basically attendance and you will required to open your cam during lessons, if you don't, according to the prof, your attendance will not be valid.
You will earn 0.25% for every time you attended the lecture with the video one, so basically you can skip several lectures.

For hw, you just have to do your best. The prof is very good and will help you adjust your marks to 100. I have a couple of frds who got 6x/100 in hw and got adjusted to 100.

for me
Class participation 4.75/5
Best 5 out of 7 homework assignments full
mid term exam 47.7/63 (mean 46.3, highest 61)
group video project 8.048/10 (mean: 7.8, highest 8.8)
final exam 70/100 (mean: 47.9, highest:89 )
at last I got an A
reviews.comment_workload:
I would say that the workload is moderate.
for the video project it's actually pretty easy, I got teammates to carry me so I didn't actually do much

the hw are out pretty frequent, but you just have to listen to lectures and most of the answers can be found online so no worries on that as well.

the most difficult part is studying for final as my exam table is too tight and I literally didn't listen to lectures for an entire month before the final. I took three days to listen back to all those lectures. so an advice is to always listen to lectures and you will be fine.
