One long question is something that I've never seen, statistics about some economic conditions. This should be something that he teaches in class but not leave the question in the final in order to let us screw up. Kind reminder: Don't choose him. Got a C+ btw
reviews.comment_workload: Really little workload, but it just makes u anxious. I forget, around 4 to 5 problem sets, i.e. homework,  they are grp assignments. Relatively easy, but again, it just makes u feel more anxious.

reviews.author: Gayauuuu
reviews.title: An immature but passionate professor
reviews.comment_content: About half of the contents are similar to DSE Economics, so at the very beginning of this course, you can easily pick up all of the knowledge. The content of this course is interesting for me (as I love Economics), but most of my friends think that it is quite boring and hard.
reviews.comment_teaching: Robin's teaching is VERY poor for most of the students. He is not good at teaching. He is just reading from the PowerPoints during lessons, so you can skip all his lessons indeed. Yet, as I had asked him some questions on Outlook, he explained them in detail. I can only say he is a passionate professor. Overall, his teaching is okay for me. I still recommend you NOT to reg him!!!
reviews.comment_grading: His grading is okay. In 20-21 fall sem, Econ 2113 switched to absolute grading scheme. In the beginning, he had already designed the cut-off BEFORE our mid-term: 85%- A range, 70%- B range... After all, he obviously overestimated us!!! I think he lowered the cut-off at last without telling us and directly released the letter grade. I get an A- with about 82% marks eventually.
reviews.comment_workload: There are only 5 problem sets for assignment. Each problem set is quite easy and short. Of course, there are mid-term as well as final. But the workload is really light overall! (BUT AGAIN, I still recommend NOT to reg Robin unless you love Economics)

reviews.author: lytt
reviews.comment_content:
All about microeconomics like oligopoly, monopoly, tax, subsidy etc.

More than a half are within DSE syllabus but there are few differences like basic game theory is not taught in DSE.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Xuan is a very nice professor as she is willing to answer students' questions and open extra office hours. She even uploaded extra practice exercises under students' demand.

However, sometimes her teachings were really boring and hard to catch up with as her powerpoint were quite wordy and some steps were missing when presenting graphs. She was just reading the powerpoint directly. Besides, she often overrun and she did not realize that.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is really good.

Homework 20%
Midterm 22.5% / 35%
Final 57.5% / 45%

Homework: full mark (basically everyone gets full mark)
Midterm:1.5 sd above mean
Final: 1.3 sd above mean

Final Grade: A

In fact, both the midterm and final were quite difficult. They asked about cases that are not taught during classes. You really need to understand all concepts instead of only going through the powerpoint before the exams. The grading is quite good even though the score is not high.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite light as there are only 5 problem sets. You can choose to work in a group of 4 and only one is responsible for handing in the homework.

reviews.author: caseycyy
reviews.comment_content: It is actually like the DSE content but more in-depth explanation of concepts.
reviews.comment_teaching: Never went to his classes so I don't know about that..
reviews.comment_grading:
Fairly good.
I just reviewed the problem sets and tutorial notes.
Got 63/100 for mid-term and 78/100 for finals, both above mean and eventually got a B. It's pretty good for a student who doesn't go to class for once.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not much workload. Just need to review the problem sets and clear the concept are fine. PPT slides aren't really useful.
There are group assignments around twice a week and it's pretty easy.

reviews.author: yan123
reviews.title: No attendance Good grading
reviews.comment_content:
I skip mostly all the lesson but still got A-.....
All Assignment, exams are difficult so u don't have to get high marks to have an A
If u are a student that can learn without teacher, that is the best professor u can find
reviews.comment_teaching:
Willing to answer students' question. However, her teaching skill is not so good therefore you may not fully understand .
Personally I think she is very nice.
reviews.comment_grading: Very good in grading.I actually don't really work hard in econ lesson. What I did was read the ppt and understand all the things inside. Eventually I got around 69 marks in total (above mean around 0.7sd) and I have a A-. All the assignment, mid-term and finals are challenging but no one can get full mark so don't be worry about that.
reviews.comment_workload: The assignment is difficult but not too much. There were 5 sets of assignment that can be done in groups. One assignment has around 10 long long questions .Most of them are difficult. Yet, as  long as you do it and submit, full mark will be given. One assignment takes around 2-5 hours to complete, depends on the quality you want.

reviews.author: vivivi
reviews.title: Good grade and adequate teaching
reviews.comment_content: The content is DSE syllabus plus some new types of curves. The concepts are not that difficult to understand.
reviews.comment_teaching:
You can get a brief picture of the content if you attend her lecture. However, it is just brief enough to let you know what kind of concept it is. So you should have do some study yourself. Reading the notes are good enough to understanding most of the thing. The best way to attend this course is to join her lectures and read the lecture notes yourself at the same time when you find she starts to explain something in a mess.

Although she is not good at teaching, she is eager to answer any questions (although not necessary explained clearly).
And also with good English with no Chinese accent.

To conclude, please choose this prof if you have an adequate self learning skills
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade.

Overall: 0.6 SD above the mean.
Grade: A

She said she will see the attendance if your mark is at the margin of the grade.
reviews.comment_workload:
Assignments are graded in full mark as long as you did the work appropriately, no matter is your answers correct or not.

You can work in your own or in group which is up to 4 people.
10 questions for each assignment.

reviews.author: stxfxtnx
reviews.title: Good grade and nice professor
reviews.comment_content:
What's Economics?
The Economic Problem
Demand and Supply
Elasticity
Efficiency and equity
Government actions in markets
Global markets in action
Possibilities, preferences, and choice
Output and costs
Perfect competition
Monopoly & price discrimination
Oligopoly & basic game theory
Public choices and public goods
Externalities
reviews.comment_teaching:
Her English is good and doesn't have much accent. She is willing to answer students' questions and is passionate about teaching. Her ppt slides are easy to follow while the practice questions she provided are not so useful for preparing the exam as the questions in the final exam are MUCH MORE DIFFICULT.

While for tutorials, although attendance is not required, Peter will only post the materials as the end of the zoom meeting. Thus, if you want to have the materials, you must stay at the meetings. Also, there is no recording for tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
Homework assignments: 20%
Exams: midterm + final exam: 80%
The total exam grade will be determined by the highest of the following two:
a) 35% midterm + 45% final
b) 22.5% midterm +57.5% final

I believe everyone can get full mark in assignments once you finish them properly as they do not mind whether you have done them correctly or not.

The midterm and final exam are difficult. The questions are very long and they are hard to understand. But don't worry, the grading is very lenient

Midterm:
Mean: 42.9/74
Median: 43.25/74
SD: 8.6
My score: 55.5/74

Final exam:
Mean: 50.9/105
Median: 48.5/105
SD: 12.8
My score: 62.5/105

I got an A in this course.
reviews.comment_workload: There are five problem sets and each has around ten questions. She will post the problem sets two to three weeks before the deadline. The problem sets are difficult and require a lot of time to discuss with your groupmates and finish.

reviews.author: DawDawDaw
reviews.title: Robin is nice & Utilize your resources wisely
reviews.comment_content: View the attachment below.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Robin's teaching is not good in classes but he does really well in solving students' difficulties.

Robin literally doesn't cover so many questions that will be appeared in exams. And he is like immersing himself into explaining some economic concepts, whether they are basic or advanced.

If you are a GPA/exam-oriented person, please just directly skip most of his lessons, except for the lesson before the mid-term exam and the lesson before the final exam. And what you should do more is trying to view and understand all the content in the textbook, then ask Robin any concepts/questions you can't grasp/solve via Gmail. He will usually reply to your email within 3 to 4 hours. That the crux of how you understand what Robin tries to teach in lessons.

Another tip is that you may directly learn the content of this course by navigating other uni websites. There are scores of free online resources. You may ask Robin any questions about the problem sets that appeared in those free online uni courses.

By the way, please skip tutorials. They are useless at all, except for the summary notes that you can review any concepts quickly in them.
reviews.comment_grading:
Problem Sets 20%

Midterm Exam 35%

Final Exam 45%
The final exam will cover all materials taught during the term.

I messed up 1 long question in my midterm, only got a mean score(about 60/100).

But I got relatively higher scores on group assignments (almost full mark, got a deduction for 0.x marks) and the final exam (messed up mc and a part of long questions, but my score is still above mean for like 7-8 marks).

*Absolute grading this year
Final grade : B+ ;(
(it is my fault, not Robin's fault)
reviews.comment_workload:
5 problem sets, which will be posted every two weeks.

Work in groups with ≤ 4 people; only one copy is required for each group.

Each PS will account for 3%; the remaining 5% will be peer evaluation scores.

Make sure all people in your group should complete the PS themselves first, then discuss and modify your final answer. That's how you learn and secure a high mark on PS.

Report any undesirable matters to Robin ( free riders/ monopolist)

reviews.author: Mivy Wenceslas
reviews.title: Good Content but Boring Professor
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1. What is Economics
Chapter 2. The Economic
Chapter 3. Demand and Supply
Chapter 4. Elasticity
Chapter 5. Efficiency and Equity
Chapter 6. Markets in Action
Chapter 7. Global  in Action
Chapter 8. Utility and Demand
Chapter 9. Possibilities, Preferences, and Choices
Chapter 11. Output and Costs
Chapter 12. Perfect Competition
Chapter 13. Monopoly
Chapter 14. Monopolistic Competition Chapter 15. Oligopoly

Some of them are in DSE syllabus but there are a lot of new content. Game theory and consumer theory are examples. Also, it talks more detailed about Monopoly, Perfect Competition and Monopolistic Competition.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Her teachings is useful, but boring. She is sometimes too fast in showing the notes, which is only available when attending the class. She is quite dull so it is easy to fall asleep in class.

Other than that, she is a good teacher. She is willing to answer questions and she provides a lot of useful insights particularly in group presentation part.

I would also like to feature her TA Mr. Jeremy To. Truly the best TA. He is willing to answer any questions, providing a lot of graphs and notes during tutorials. He also does what he could in the shortest time possible. He is a wonderful TA.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class Participation 5%
Assignments 20%
Midterm Exam 25%
Group Video Project 15%
Final Exam 35%

You only earn 0.25% class participation mark when you turn on the camera.

It counts best 5 out of 7 assignments. As long as you have shown that you tried to attempt the homework, you will score full mark, regardless of your initial score. So you could get full mark if you score only 50 marks. It is quite lenient.

Mid-term is quite difficult, especially the short questions. They are hard to answer.

The group presentation is lenient in general. Most people get around the mean without a big difference.

The final exam is incredibly difficult. The short questions in particular is really testing your knowledge and the answer can be too vague. The analytical questions involve a lot of calculations that may cost a lot of marks if not handled properly. The MCs are also quite tricky.

Participation: Full
Assignments: Full
Group Project: 7.5/10 (Low:6 Mean:7.8 High:8.8)
Mid-term: 49.9/63 (Low:22.9 Mean:46.3 High:61)
Final: 73/100 (Low:0 Mean:47.9 High:89)
Grade:A
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fairly light considering there is only a group project and 7 assignments to do. However, each assignment may take you some time since they are quite difficult. It is particularly demanding to attend almost every lesson since it counts your participation mark.

reviews.author: Kanade
reviews.comment_content:
Covers basic topics in Microeconomics
Topics covered in DSE Economics will be discussed in the first few characters including Elasticity and PPF.
After that, there will be new contents including indifference curve, pricing and cost of firms in monopoly and perfect competition market, and Basic Game Theory (Nash Equilibrium and Cournot Competition)

The entire content is mostly easy. Going through all notes should already be enough to understand the content.
reviews.comment_teaching: I can not fairly judge the quality of teaching due to not attending most of the lectures and never attended any tutorial. However, according to my few experiences, teaching quality is fair. Professor Ding can present economic theories in quite understandable while interesting manner by demonstrating and explaining with real-life examples.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two Grading Scheme:
1. Problem Set 9%, Quiz 40%, Final 51%
2. Problem Set 9%, Quiz 24% (Best 3) Final 67%
Problem set doesn't have to be completed, submission of any files can receive full mark

Quiz 1: 16/20
(Mean 15.8)
Quiz 2: 17/20
(Mean 16.5)
Quiz 3: 12/20
(Mean 14.3)
Quiz 4: 17/20
(Mean 15.9)
Quiz 5: 15/20
(Mean 15.1, SD 2.72)
Highest for all quiz is 20/20

Final: 53.43/120
(Mean 46.79/120, Median 46.17/120, SD 14.01, Highest 84.1)

Final Grade: B
Have everything around mean and getting B is the normal case I presume
reviews.comment_workload:
Problem Sets is not compulsory to complete due to the reasons mentioned in the grading section.

Contents of quizzes are elementary. You  can easily get high mark by reading notes once and complete the MC part of given problem sets. However, due to constrained time (20 questions in 25 mins), it's easy to make careless mistakes

Final is quite difficult and, I suppose things wouldn't change much even if you study a lot. So just invest a few days and go through notes and do a few past papers which you can find online (not the given one since it's no match with the real difficulty) will already be enough

reviews.author: Iloveusthehe
reviews.comment_content:
Microeconomics
Not very easy but not so hard at the same time
It is related to what you learned in high school.
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite good with many details.
reviews.comment_grading:
HW
5 Quizzes
Final

There are 2 schemes
Scheme 1) Count 3 quizzes only and weigh heavier for final
Scheme 2) Count all the quizzes

The mean for each quiz was quite high. Every time it would be a 1x/20. Make sure you have to keep studying in order to get a full mark or a nearly full mark in the quizzes as the final exam would be hard.

I scored above mean for everything so I got an A-. Good luck.
reviews.comment_workload: Not so heavy. Only one HW set each week.

reviews.author: mmcy
reviews.comment_content:
Similar to DSE content. If you have studied Economics in  secondary school, you can easily understand the concept taught in this course

2 Schemes for overall grading:
Scheme 1: 6 out of 7 Problem Sets@ 1.5% each (9% in total)
Quizzes(8% each) All five: 40%
Final Exam(cumulative): 51%

Scheme 2: 6 out of 7 Problem Sets@ 1.5% each (9% in total)
Quizzes(8% each) Best three: 24%
Final Exam(cumulative): 67%
reviews.comment_teaching: She is willing to answer your questions, and she always likes to interact with her students.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is quite good!
6 Quizzes in total: above mean in 3 quizzes and below mean in 3 quizzes. There are 20 MC questions in each quiz.

For the final, it was an online exam and it was quite difficult. Many students got a low score. The mean is 51.5/100 in my section, and I scored below mean.

Make sure you hand in your assignments as it counts 9% towards your final grade.

My final grade: B-. I think it is quite good. I get several quizzes below mean and my final below mean. I can still get a B- overall.
reviews.comment_workload: Every 2 week there is one quiz, and there are 7 problem sets in total. Quite a heavy workload compared to other business courses.

reviews.author: 清水灣Q王
reviews.comment_content:
The course is quite easy in the beginning, especially for DSE students. Content for the first few lessons includes basic trade theory (DSE macro stuff), demand and supply, basic concepts etc.. Things get a bit tougher after that, chapters such as utility and indifference curve are completely new to DSE students. Also, note that this course involves a lot of basic calculation when solving problems in assignments and tests (e.g. calculate equilibrium price and quantity with equations of the demand and supply curve), so the question types are quite different from DSE. I do think that it is useful for students that are going to choose econ related majors and provide sufficient basic insight to the microeconomics field.
Lecture content are as follows:
Chapter 1: What is Economics?
Chapter 2: The Economic Problem
Part 2: How Markets Work
Chapter 3: Demand and Supply (1); Demand and Supply (2)
Chapter 4: Elasticity (1)
Chapter 4: Elasticity (2)
Chapter 5: Efficiency and Equity
Chapter 6: Government Actions in Markets
Chapter 7: Global Markets in Action (1)
Chapter 7: Global Markets in Action (2)
Part 3: Households’ Choices
Chapter 8: Utility and Demand
Midterm Exam covers Chapter 1 through 8
Part 4: Firms and Markets
Chapter 9: Possibilities, Preferences, and Choice
Chapter 11: Output and Costs (1)
Chapter 11: Output and Costs (2)
Chapter 12: Perfect Competition
Chapter 13: Monopoly
Chapter 14: Monopolistic Competition
Chapter 15: Oligopoly
Part 5: Market Failure and Government
Chapter 17: Externalities
Part 6: Factor Markets, Inequality, and Uncertainty
Chapter 18: Markets for Factors of Production
Chapter 19: Economic Inequality
Chapter 20: Uncertainty and Information
Final exam covers all the topics taught.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teaching of this professor, to be honest, is satisfactory. For a Mainland professor, he does not show much of an accent and explains concepts quite well, however, I would say that his lessons are a bit boring. I did not attend much of the lectures as I  could self-learn the course material, and more importantly, attendance was not a grading requirement for this course(lol).
reviews.comment_grading:
Problem Sets  20%
Mid-term         35%
Final               45%
The mid-term exam is extremely difficult, the mean for MT was something around 30% which is unusual for a basic course like this in my opinion. The final, that was conducted online, was much easier though (weird for an open-book open-Internet exam), questions asked were basic stuff in general.
For me, I got 75% in my mid-term and 92% in my final, overall I got 83.7% and it was good enough to grant me an A grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is acceptable. Only 1 problem set is distributed per week and each group of 3-4 people submit 1 copy of the answers before lessons. Mid-term and final requires quite a bit of work if you are to aim for a higher grade.

reviews.author: yuyanb
reviews.comment_content:
Course outline:
Chp1: what is economics
Chp2: the economic problems
Chp3: demand and supply
chp4: Elasticity
Chp5: efficiency and equity
chp6: Government actions in the markets
chp7
chp9 Possibilities, preference and choices
chp11: output and cost
chp 12:perfect competition
Chp 13: Monopoly
Chp15: oligopoly
Chp16+17:Public choices, public goods and healthcare

If you take econ back in secondary school, it should be easy for you to handle most of the topic in this course. The lecture note will be sufficient for the midterm. However, I suggest you to pay a little more attention to the game theory part. It is pretty tricky but interesting topic.
reviews.comment_teaching: Erm he is a bit boring tbh, probably because his lesson is right after the lunchtime. So I didn't go to class after the third lessons...
reviews.comment_grading: the grading is good. I got above mean around 1sd in my midterm and above 1.5 sd in my final. I managed to get a A- without attending most of the classes.
reviews.comment_workload: This course has a relatively light workload. Throughout the whole semester, there is only four problem sets which can be submitted on group basis. So basically, you just need to do two or three questions if you got group mates.

reviews.author: noneedtoknowwho

Much more advanced DSE topic. The concept behind it is definitely harder.

midterm: 55/100
final: 48/100
overall: B-

reviews.comment_teaching:
Basically he just read the PowerPoint. It is quite hard to catch his meaning since he stuttered quite often... He rushes through the content in the last few weeks because he cannot finish it. No attendance is taken so nearly half of the class disappeared after week 2.

The tutorial is quite helpful. The attendance is seemed to be higher than the lecture's one.

homework assignments 20%
1 midterm 35%

Exam questions are similar to those from assignments. You could do well in exams by only revising the assignments. The grading is quite fair.
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload. 4 homework sets in total. You can do it in a group of 5 members. Almost everyone gets a 9x something.

reviews.author: KH037
reviews.comment_content: More than the DSE syllabus a little bit only. For the first few chapters, they are just the DSE Econ, which doesn't,t require us to spend lots of time in these topics
reviews.comment_teaching: Some of the online questions will be asked in the class.
reviews.comment_grading:
There will be 5 quizzes,6 HW and 1 final exam.
Two scoring scheme, it will be better for doing all the quizzes and the mean is really high. You may need to work hard for it.
Good grade.
reviews.comment_workload: Not many things need to be done.

reviews.author: breeeee
reviews.title: Amazing prof!
reviews.comment_content:
It's a lot similar to IB economics so those who have done it will find it really easy to understand.
The Prof also makes it more interesting by including some real-life examples to explain concepts and exceptions which makes the class interesting, especially if you're already familiar with the content.
reviews.comment_teaching:
She explains things very clearly, is friendly and approachable and is happy to answer any questions in the middle of her lecture. She really does her best to make sure everyone is able to follow what she teaches.
In addition to that, she is also good at keeping the class engaged. She asks us questions and asks us to use iPRS on our phone to answer MCQs in class (not graded), to test our understanding.
I must also point out that it was one of the few classes I didn't fall asleep in.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading was decent enough.
Though I wasn't completely satisfied with the way things were done (exams were online because of protests and I feel like I could have done better otherwise), my final grade was decent, I got a B.
reviews.comment_workload: The professor really went out of her way to lighten our workload since we are first-year students. So we didn't have any mid-terms, just 5 online MCQ quizzes which were quite easy, and then a final. She gives us homework questions before the quiz which prepares you for the content of each quiz, which I found really helpful and convenient. The best part is that the homework isn't even graded so you can choose to do it at your own convenience.

reviews.author: kyddet
reviews.comment_content: Content is not difficult. For those who took DSE Econ should be really easy to follow. The first part of the course is basically basic econ knowledge like demand and supply. Then he will touch a little about about game theory but the concepts are relatively easy and should be able to handle.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor explain everything in detail and really clear. Also he answers everything students ask really detailed and will make sure everyone understands everything before he proceeds. If he sees someone looking confused, he will repeat what he trying to say one million times. He is also really nice and always shares his own stories during lessons.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is fair. If you work hard and keep your mind clear during exams, getting an A should not be difficult. For me I messed up my midterm (got some score close to mean) so my grade was not that great. But some people can get scores really close to full marks or even full marks.
reviews.comment_workload: Workload is not too big. There are 2-3 assignments we have to complete and professor expects us to complete them in groups of 4. Yet you can also do it own your own as the assignments are not that difficult to handle. Attendance is not compulsory. One midterm, one final exam.

reviews.author: TheGoat
reviews.title: Need to reg this professor!!
reviews.comment_content:
Topics Covered:
Demand and Supply
Elasticity
Efficiency and Equity
Government Actions in Markets
Global Markets in Action
Consumer Theory
Firms and Markets
Output and Costs
Perfect Competition
Monopoly & Price Discrimination
Oligopoly & Basic Game Theory
Market Failure, Public Choices and Public Goods, Externalities

Mostly DSE stuff, but they are more complicated and need more effort to understand. However, overall amazing content for those who want to learn more.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching is excellent. He has a sense of humour which we all like to attend his class. As a game theorist, he explained game theory in a funny but also interactive way which gave the whole class clear explanation of concepts. I like his teaching as he has a good (though Korean) accent and also he is a friendly guy who will answer your every question asked.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is fair enough. The best part about grading is hard work pays off. There is only 1 mid term,1 final and 5 homework in total. There is no attention needed. His examinations and homework has no MC as he hates them (I hate MC as well). It is fair for everyone. Although his examinations are hard, the mean is low as well. Therefore, there is no need to be scared that he will be a killer or something. Just study and all things will go well.

Mid Term: 170/200 (mean around 135 because i forgot)
HW1: 90/90
HW2: 245/265
Final: ???/200
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload: There is only 1 mid term and 1 final, meaning the workload is not that high. Also, for all the homework, there are guidelines if you attend the tutorials and there is 2 homework in total submitted in this semester due to special occasion. However, usually, there are 5 homework for 1 semester in Professor Lim's class.

Normal.

-will always ask students if they have any questions before going to another concepts

reviews.comment_grading:
-quite good
There are two schemes for grading
Scheme 1
Problem sets: 8%
Quizzes (8% each): All five - 40%
Cumulative final exam: 52%
Scheme 2
Problem sets: 8%
Quizzes (8% each): The best three - 24%

reviews.author: grindingalways
reviews.comment_content:
Not too difficult in general. You will learn some DSE-related content e.g. PPF, demand & supply, elasticity and efficiency first, a little bit more advanced but not hard to catch up at all. Next up you will learn some new content, here are a few examples:
1. 'preference, indifference curves': basically teach you how the demand curve and law of demand are derived from
2. 'output and cost': include A LOT OF graphs such that you can perfectly explain how the supply curve and law of supply are derived from (please spend more time on revision)
3. 'market structures': perfect competition, monopoly and oligopoly, something you have learned in DSE before but more advanced and in-depth
4. 'public good': this topic sounds more difficult as it seems, because Prof Lim has combined it with game theory (his research interest) and it might be a bit difficult to follow in the beginning. Just revise a few more times and you should be able to comprehend
reviews.comment_teaching: His English accent is not good, so you might have difficulty in understanding what he's trying to say in the first few classes. You will adapt to it though. He made mistakes in class quite frequently when explaining the materials, but I think he's trying to make the class a bit less boring haha. He is a nice professor who will not show any weariness no matter how stupid your question is. The lecture notes are clear and not redundant. He also encouraged us to work hard and shared some of his history, which are absolutely intriguing.
reviews.comment_grading:
Original scheme:
Homework assignments (4 in total) 20%
1 midterm (100 minutes) 35%
1 final exam (3 hours) 45%
Now the final exam was shortened to 2 hours, and we only handed in 2 assignments. I don't know the respective weighting after these have changed.
My result:
HW1: 90/90 (mean 86.2)
HW2: 260/265 (mean 242)
Mid term: 170/200 (mean 140.1)
Final: Unknown
A in the end.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite high. The homework set problems are NOT easy, and you really need to sort them out while discussing with your teammates (we did the homework in a group of 3-4 people). Thank god we did not have to do the remaining ones. Mid term and final all in the format of 3 long questions. You'd expect to utilize all the time given to perfect your answers in order to stand out.

reviews.author: KT8144
reviews.title: Extremely good grades with reasonable workload
reviews.comment_content:
Similar to DSE Economics with a few new topics like Strategical Behaviour and Monopoly.
Ch. 0 Introduction
Ch. 1 Thinking like economists
Ch. 2 Specialization and Gain from Trade
Ch. 3 Demand and Supply
Ch. 4 Elasticity
Ch. 5 Efficiency and Equity
Ch. 6 Government meets Market
Ch. 8 Utility and Demand
Ch. 9 Possibilities, Preferences and Choices
Ch. 10 Organizing Production
Ch. 11 Output and Costs
Ch. 12 Perfect Competition
Ch. 13 Monopoly
Ch. 15 Strategic Interaction and Oligopoly
Ch. 17 Externalities

(Skipped Ch. 7 Tariff, Ch. 14 Monopolistic Competition and Ch. 16 Public Goods is merged into the lecture notes of Ch. 17)
reviews.comment_teaching:
First of all, Prof. Ding doesn't take attendance. In the first lecture, she already said: "attending my lesson or not is your freedom, but I won't provide any make-up sessions because you are responsible for attending the lessons on time".

To be frank, Prof. Ding's teaching is a bit boring. Basically, she directly reads through the lecture notes, which are the powerpoints of the textbooks with maybe some modification made by her. On the other hand, she opts to ask questions frequently. In her lecture notes, there are some MCQs for clarifying concepts, and she may ask the questions through iPRS.

Prof. Ding cares a lot about "concepts". She always asks us to explain certain concepts in a way that "your grandparents would understand". She tries to use many examples so that students can master the skills, not in a way of memorizing but really understanding it. Sometimes the concepts are very different from the DSE syllabus and you may not be able to digest them within a short time.

There is also a tutorial session once per week. I personally think that our TA Peter is quite good. Prof. Ding would ask Peter to explain some difficult concepts in lectures or teach us some mathematical skills that are useful in the course. Peter would give us a handout at the beginning of the tutorial. It contains some key concepts (with explanation) and some simple exercise. Peter would try to discuss and explain all the questions in the handout if possible. He welcomes students asking him questions, although sometimes we may not be able to really solve the problem.
reviews.comment_grading:
In my opinion, Prof. Ding is one of the best professors in terms of grading. First, she mentioned in the first lecture that she would give out as many A's and B's as possible (like 15-20% A's or even more). Besides, she provides 2 grading schemes so that students may still have a chance to get a good grade if they unfortunately missed some quizzes or performed poorly in some quizzes.

Components counting towards final grade:
Problems Sets, Online Quizzes and Final Exam (will be explained in detail below and in "workload" part)

Scheme 1
Problem Sets 9% (1.5%@, counts 6 out of 7)
Canvas Online Quizzes 40% (8%@, 5 in total)
Final Exam 51%

Scheme 2
Problem Sets 9% (1.5%@, counts 6 out of 7)
Canvas Online Quizzes 24% (8%@, best 3 out of 5)
Final Exam 67%

Obviously Prof. Ding provides 2 schemes so that students will not be drastically worse off if they performed poorly in either one of the components.

My results: (My final percentage is nearly the same under the two schemes so I use scheme 1 for more information)

Problem Sets 9% (full marks, in which everyone do get)
Online Canvas Quizzes 33.6%
Quiz 1 (Ch. 3-4)         17/20, mean 16.5
Quiz 2 (Ch. 5-6)         19/20, mean 17.2
Quiz 3 (Ch. 7-8)         18/20, mean 14.4
Quiz 4 (Ch. 10-11)     15/20, mean 16.5
Quiz 5 (Ch. 12-13)     15/20, mean 15.1

Final Exam                 38.6%
                                   (75.77/100, mean 51.5, SD 14.74)
(*this year's situation was different from the past, please refer to the "workload" part)
Total percentage under scheme 1: around 81.2%
Final letter grade: A

The highest mark in the final exam was 88.5%, which was one SD higher than my score. Besides, I didn't perform as well as the others in the quizzes because the highest mark for all the quizzes were full mark. However, I still managed to get an A, which was out of my expectation. I would roughly estimate that Prof. Ding has at least given 20% student an A range, which is very generous.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is very light, or even 0 in my opinion. Apart from the lectures and the tutorials, all you need to do is a few problem sets, which contains MCQs and short/long questions related to the latest chapters taught. The "exciting" point is that Prof. Ding said she won't check the answers of your submission, i.e. as long as you upload something, marks will be awarded.

The online quizzes are also not as stressful as mid-term exams, because each quiz only contains 20 MCQs, in which you need to finish it within 30 minutes. Each quiz only covers 2 chapters, so you don't need to always keep revising.

*Special Arrangement for Final Exam this year
The final exam was changed to an online format regarding the fact that the school campus was closed and all in-campus lectures were canceled since early November.
The final exam was 130 marks in total, which consists of 20 MCQs (2 marks@each question, 40 in total) and 7 short or long questions (ranging from 8-21 marks each). The exam length was 100 minutes.
Although it was called an "online exam", only the MCQs and first 3 short questions were genuinely online. For the remaining 4 long questions, we needed to write all the answers in a piece of paper, then take a photo of the answer sheet with your student ID card, finally upload the .jpg (only .jpg is accepted) in Canvas.
To be honest, I think that the time allowed was not sufficient in the final exam. For example, we needed to finish an 8-12 mark short question within 5 minutes (including time for uploading the image). I was not able to finish some of the first few questions as a result.

Up until when this review was written, I still haven't received any information about the specific scores of each question that I got in the final exam (except for MCQs). Peter only announced the total score after translating the exam in a 100-marks total.

reviews.author: Studdas
reviews.title: Course Review of ECON 2113
reviews.comment_content:
Microeconomics analyzes the market behaviour of individual actors (consumers, firms, governments, etc.) in order to understand their decision-making processes. The course focusses on key concepts in microeconomics and basic tools to understand the allocation mechanisms of markets.
The syllabus is as follows -
Introduction
Demand and Supply
Consumer Theory
Firms and Markets - Output and Costs, Perfect Competition, Monopoly and Price Discrimination, Oligopoly and basic Game Theory.
Market Failure - Public Choice and Public Goods, Economics of Environment
Uncertainty and Information
Note - The content tested is cumulative.
reviews.comment_teaching:
1. He is a good teacher, he explains things well but you will see that he rushes the content which leads to confusion.
2. The review class he conducts is helpful as it may give you an insight into the final exam.
3. You can go to him for doubts anytime. He replies to your emails very fast.
4. He cracks some jokes sometimes which are funny.
5. The tutorials held by the TA, Icy are very good and well explained so attend them to understand the concepts.
reviews.comment_grading:
4-6 homework assignments 20% (submit the homework before the deadline otherwise it will not be collected.)
1 midterm (2 hours) 35%
1 final exam (3 hours) 45%
Total - 100%
Grading is fair. The higher you are from the mean, the more you score.
The midterm and final are based on the problem sets given so if you solve them well then your examinations will be easy.
No attendance and no cheatsheet.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload for this course was fairly high.
The homework was quite tough and the answers are not available so it took us a while to get them right.
Towards the end, the TA did not care about your answers so everyone was getting 100%
Make sure to study before your exams to get a high grade.

reviews.author: JasonWong
reviews.title: Should read if you have studied microeconomic modules in IAL
reviews.comment_content:
The contents of the course are very similar to the AS and A2 modules of microeconomics in IAL but some chapters have additional knowledge and compared to IAL some concepts are discussed more in depth. However, some of the same concepts taught in this course and IAL now have graphical applications (for example, the price effect of price change of goods which separates into substitution effect and income effect will be illustrated with indifference curves and budget line) and some same concepts don't require graphs (for example the kinked demand curve is not taught for the oligopoly chapter). It also has more but basic maths used as IAL doesn't really teach econ maths.
Chapters:
0. Introduction
1. Thinking like an economists (sounds weird but basically, you are doing this in IAL econ)
2. Specialisation and trade
3. Demand and Supply
4. Elasticity
5. Efficiency and Equity
6. Government meets Market
8. Utility and demand
9. Possibilities, Preferences and Choices
10. Organizing Production
11. Output and costs
12. Perfect Competition
13. Monopoly
15. Strategic Interaction and Oligopoly
17. Externalities
reviews.comment_teaching:
I genuinely believe the professor teaches very well, you may think that because you have learnt most of the content in the module (if you studied the same IAL modules as I did) you don't have to go to lectures but I recommend you do go to the lectures as
1. she skims through a lot of content as she does understand that people enrolled in this course have pretty good economic knowledge but does so according to DSE economics, not IAL economics so you won't be bored listening to stuff you already know
2. most chapters have some additional content that is taught which are the ones she goes through thoroughly and I felt that the graphs were understood when explained
3. she gives a lot of good examples and is willing to discuss with students
4. her lectures are actually really enjoyable as I feel like it had a really good balance between teaching course content, in-class iPRS exercises, discussions and most importantly she speaks close to perfect English without much of an accent
5. her slides on canvas are not the same as the slides used in class, the difference being that there are no answers to questions and some blanks that she wants you to fill in in class. But she does upload the complete version on the canvas for final revision.

NB the tutorials had some revision of content from lecture and sometimes new information or application of knowledge. Should go through as although the things taught in the tutorials do show up in the final.
reviews.comment_grading:
I believe the grading is very reasonable as she tries to give out as much A range and B ranges.
Two grading schemes and TA will calculate both and use the higher one
Scheme 1
Problem sets: 8%
Quizzes (8% each): All five - 40%
Cumulative final exam: 52%
Scheme 2
Problem sets: 8%
Quizzes (8% each): The best three - 24%
Cumulative final exam: 68%

NB: problem sets are not graded, as long as you hand in something even blank pages you get the 8% for the 8 problem sets
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is very light, might have to spend some time to go over slides if she skimmed through it in lecture, highly recommend you read the textbook, should do the MCQ practice she gives you for each quiz if you want full marks (pretty sure it was for finals but I still used it).

個prof系native speaker，但成日口吃，講得太快又hang機，心諗你講慢d我地吸收到，你又唔使成日hang機咪好。凈系對住ppt教，最後臨近final前先叫做有寫下野教下野。

由於上佢堂真心悶，好多時候我都系上堂既時候坐系後邊自己學（唔好學我咁唔聽書）/訓教。 由開sem一大班人到最後20-30人都知發生咩事。靠自己啦！

本身個prof就比硬E，但TA Guo Bing好有心教，雖然大陸口音重但唔影響理解，notes精簡而且教得唔錯。最後叫我地比分prof（學期尾有個比唔同course prof分數）唔好太嚴格，因為都係第一次來。咁好既TA真係少見
reviews.comment_grading:
20%Homework（4份）: 100+100+100+95 （聽聞好似唔會認真改，只系睇你有無心去做，唔好hea做就ok）
35%Midterm: 173/200 (mean 146, sd around 28)
45%Final: 69/100 (mean 64.8 sd not announced)
Overall B+

其實final出得真係勁簡單，完全系佢最尾lecture video教既幾題同功課入邊既，但就怪我之前miss左太多野，最尾想抱下佛腳都趕唔切。所以要定期清左d concept，唔好拖！
reviews.comment_workload: 其實workload就凈系得功課，但佢比d功課真係多到嘔，試過一題入邊唔知有7/8個小分題，但大部分都係wooyoung lim既hw到抄既，所以想攞高grade既就一定要攞到sources。遇到佢可以開始自學，始終系大學自學好過聽prof。

reviews.author: Ust fishman
reviews.comment_content: The content is quite good.Based on DSE syllabus with some additional more complicated concepts. Content is not hard to understand. Although some graph may be a bit hard for dse students, it is easy to catch if you study hard.
reviews.comment_teaching: Her accent is quite good among the ust professors.However, the lecture is actually boring. The professor didn't really skip much even she knew you have learnt those topics in Secondary School. And her voice would make you feel sleepy. It is alright to just read the powerpoint and attend the exam.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is fair. But the final is really hard, especially the long question part since you wont know what the professors expect you to answer. It is very horrible even you have studied all the notes. But I think as long as you read the Powerpoint slides thoroughly and did some problem sets also try to draw the graphs required then it would be fine for your grade. The mean is very low in the final exam.
reviews.comment_workload: Very light workload. Although she requires a lot of problem sets, they will be graded once you have submitted. So feel free to work on the problem set.

reviews.author: TY Tang
reviews.comment_content:
Required textbook: M. Parkin: “Microeconomics,” 12th ed., Pearson International, 2016.

Chapters covered: Chapters 1-7, 9, 11-13, 15-17.

Topics:
- What is economics
- Demand and supply
- Elasticity
- Efficiency and equity
- Government intervention/trade restriction
- Possibilities, preferences, choices
- Costs and output
- Perfect competition, monopoly, oligopoly
- Basic game theory
- Externalities

As the first course in microeconomics, the course is basically the same as HKDSE content with new ideas on how the demand curve is derived, and oligopoly. Nothing extra special in this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
As a visiting professor, Professor Neary does a so-so job for this class. His time management seems to be an issue. Additionally, at times it has been rather difficult to approach him through emails.

He tends to go off track quite often, but to be quite fair, his ideas are often related to the subject, e.g. the beauty contest game by Keynes, Bertrand model, Tobin's ice-cream test. On the good side, he is very willing to answer questions after class, and answers them clearly.

The TA, Icy does a phenomenal job in the tutorials. Her notes are really clear and insightful, and helps one understand the material well. She responds to email very quickly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading:

Homework - problem sets (group work): 20%
Mid-term: 35%
Finals: 45%

From my experience, it is not difficult to get a good grade in the course. If one attends the lectures and the tutorials, the mid-terms and finals are relatively easy. For the problem sets, only one or two questions count for the grades, the questions are alright.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload are basically the 4 problem sets, which aren't that much. Relative to other courses, ECON2113 has a light workload.

reviews.author: GGG
reviews.comment_content: Content is quite easy. The full syllabus should be listed in others' comments. Overall, it is merely an extension to the DSE syllabus. But beware that some content tested in the exam is only mentioned in the powerpoint but not in the reference book.
reviews.comment_teaching: His teaching is terrible and hard to understand, since he stutters quite a bit. I skipped all the lessons after the first few. For me it is more productive and efficient to skip all of the lessons and revise with the powerpoints and reference book on your own.
reviews.comment_grading:
There is only 5-6 questions in the exam and the exam duration is well more than enough. With sufficient preparation, one would expect to finish the exam with more than half an hour left. In fact, in the final exam, at least 30% of students have left the exam hall with more than an hour remaining. This gives you an idea of how adequate the duration is.

In terms of the difficulty, it is not that difficult at all, with sufficient revision and practice with past papers and assignments. For the final exam, its difficulty is similar to the homework given. One of the exam questions is literally identical to the last set of homework, so make sure you pay more attention to those.
In the end I got an A. It could have been better had I knew some content tested is only mentioned in his powerpoint slides before the mid term.
reviews.comment_workload: In general, the workload is alright with 4-5 set of homework (7-8 questions each). But the last assignment was simply unreasonable, since he only distributed it to us during the study break, which is one week before the exam period.

reviews.author: laurenn
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1: What is Economics?
Chapter 2: The Economic Problem
Chapter 3: Demand and Supply
Chapter 4: Elasticity
Chapter 5: Efficiency and Equity
Chapter 6: Government Actions in Markets
Chapter 7: Global Markets in Action
-- Midterm --
Chapter 9: Possibilities, Preferences, and Choice
Chapter 11: Output and Costs
Chapter 12: Perfect Competition
Chapter 13: Monopoly & Price Discrimination
Chapter 15: Oligopoly & Basic Game Theory
Chapter 16: Public Choices and Public Goods
Chapter 17: Economics of Environment (Mostly skipped)
Chapter 20: Uncertainty and Information (Completely skipped)
-- Final --

The topics are almost the same as the ones covered in AP Micro.

The questions on the midterm and final were mostly based on the examples he did in class or the homework questions, so focus on reviewing those rather than memorizing the textbook. Basically, if you can do the homework questions, the final is easy.

Also, he *said* that the final would be cumulative, but I think it only covered stuff taught after the midterm.
reviews.comment_teaching:
His teaching got better towards the end of the semester, especially when he taught Game Theory, which was actually quite interesting. He does stutter a bit, so it might be a bit confusing sometimes, but if you ask him after class, it's a lot easier to understand.

Most people either don't go to the lectures or show up and don't listen, but I think you should just mainly focus on his own examples, in which he'll take out a piece of paper and start drawing graphs or proving axioms.

The TA printed out chapter summaries for us, and would go over the answers to the hw in the tutorials. Icy teaches really well, and can explain the concepts to you clearly.
reviews.comment_grading:
4 Homework Assignments: 20% (More based on effort than accuracy)
Midterm: 35% (Mean: 147/200, SD: 29)
Final: 45% (Mean: 64.8/100, SD: unknown)

Only got a bit higher than mean for the midterm, but full marks for the homework assignments and final.
Final grade = A.
reviews.comment_workload: There were only 4 hw assignments throughout the semester, and each one was between 6 and 12 questions long. You can also make your own groups for the assignment. Most of the questions seem to be the same as Wooyoung Lim's assignments. However, as long as you put in effort, you should get full marks for the assignments regardless of accuracy. Again, go to the tutorials and understand the answers to the hw questions to do well on the final.

reviews.author: zitaho0329
reviews.title: Boring, hard to understand
reviews.comment_content: The content itself is interesting, some are almost the same with the DSE one, but the new one is hard to understand and learn.

reviews.comment_grading: I don't know how he grades.

reviews.title: Not that difficult if you've learnt economics before
reviews.comment_content:
You can see attachment for the syllabus.

Most of the contents are similar to DSE econ so it is not difficult. Topics after mid-term could be challenging comparatively but still not that difficult.

He did not finish all chapter because he did not have enough time for that.
reviews.comment_teaching:
You can skip all the lectures and attend the tutorials.
Philip is not experienced as this is the first time he teaches this course. He just reads from the powerpoint and you can see people falling asleep or playing games in class. He also stutters a lot.

Tutorials are more useful as Icy explains the concepts very clearly. If you are confused after attending the lecture, just go to the tutorial and ask the tutor. Homework solutions are discussed during tutorials and this is the only way you know the solutions so attend the tutorials.

D for lectures but A for tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fair. Reviewing session was available for mid-term but not final.

Final exam        45%
Homework        20%

Median        151/200
Max             200/200
SD               29

Final statistics

Not difficult to get 100% for homework too.

Total 82.3%
Grade B+
reviews.comment_workload:
4 homework sets, usually due in 1 week
Most if not all questions are from Wooyoung and maybe some from Philip himself.
There are some out of syllabus questions and the questions are demanding but you can share your workload with your groupmates.
1 homework set per month which means we had to hand in our last homework during study break.

reviews.author: lc09
reviews.title: Rubbish!!!!
reviews.comment_content:
There are 13 chapters (refer to other comments as I think this is not important to mention). 2 chapters are cut simply because he can't finish.

Why I said it's not important to mention the chapters is that some chapters or concepts are totally useless and won't appear in exam. Some topics only appear in 1 out of 70 slides (e.g. Transitive and completeness) in one chapter would cover 15% of the examination :)



All the contents important is indeed those appear in your homework. Make sure you understand everything in the homework as he just simply copy the homework question into exam!
(He even didn't change the numbers......)

Textbook is useless as professor directly use Pearson Longman PowerPoint (very lazy!!). The PowerPoint, although written by the editor of textbook, is also very poor and contains lots of typo.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I would give an A grade for tutor but an E grade for professor (felt sorry for the tutor as it's not her fault)


The professor simply don't understand what he taught! He just used all the materials from Wooyoung Lim and can't even speak fluently (although he is a native English speaker...) This also makes lecture EXTREMELY BORING as we need to waste time listening to his hesitation and shuttering.

He also like to upload the PowerPoint right before the lecture (5 minutes before lecture start......) so self-study is not possible either.



The tutor, however, knows the relationship between different concepts very well, and can tell the main points of 3-4 chapters precisely in just a 50 minute tutorial session.

Homework solutions are discussed in tutorial sessions. However professors don't upload and don't allow us to look at the solution (what a stupid idea) and you need to take pictures quickly by your phone. Make sure you attend tutorials and understand the solution as the questions would appear in exams.

You can just simply attend all the tutorial sessions but skip all the lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
4 Homework: all 100/100
Mid term: 168/200 [Mean 145.9]
Final: 75/100 [Mean 64.8]

Final grade: B+


4 Homework: 20%
Finish all questions to get 100 (no need to be correct). Steps are not required as they just check the final answer. You would find some questions very challenging but make sure you understand as this would appear in exams.

Mid term exam: 35%
Final exam: 45%
Everything in homework (even the numbers are not changed). Although some questions may be different, it is based on the situation in homework. So don't waste time revising the textbook or those poor lecture slides
reviews.comment_workload:
Homework quite difficult, but you can find partners to finish the questions with you. You can also find partners from other lecture sessions taught by professor Neary.

One silly thing is that one of his homework was given AFTER the last lecture. That means you need to submit your homework during study break and listen to his tutorial while you are having other examinations. Very poor planning!

reviews.author: pinkckwc
reviews.comment_content: Most of the topics taught were similar to the high school, but some of them were quite difficult to understand, and the graphs were somehow confusing
reviews.comment_teaching: the professor was willing to answer your questions, but her voice was a little bit sharp. Her powerpoint was sometimes interesting.
reviews.comment_grading: I got A- and I was more than one SD in final exam. There were two schemes for you to calculate the final grading and the higher would be adopted for your GPA.
reviews.comment_workload: There were sometimes assignment from the textbook and IPRS during lessons.

reviews.author: puddypie
reviews.title: EZ PZ
reviews.comment_content:
I've took Econs during A-Levels. I can say that this course is more concepts dependant. It does not require you to write essays nor formulate synthesis, which may cause some frustration amongst us A-Levels students as we can no longer bullshit our way through.
That aside, content is relatively simple and straightforward.
reviews.comment_teaching: I've personally never once stepped into the lecture hall before. Attendance is not taken and I've never bothered to look at the slides. I do however read through the textbook. So I'll give this an A.
reviews.comment_grading:
5 Quizzes taken online and 1 Final exam.
There are 2 different grading system, 1 gives more weighting towards your quizzes and the other gives more weighting towards your finals. The TA will calculate which score you achieved better and will allocate the results accordingly.
Some marks are allocated towards 'Homework" but you can just submit a blank sheet of paper cause it's not graded based on effort but submission.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload for this course is non-existent.
The only thing to note is that you need to work hard for the Final Exams cause the content is will hit you like a wrecking ball if you've been slacking throughout the semester.

reviews.author: agatha
reviews.title: Super good grade!
reviews.comment_content: The content before mid term is the same as DSE Microeconomics. However, the materials covered after the midterm is much harder and include some calculation. Topics covered after the mid term include but not limited to, budget line, indifference curve, monopoly, oligopoly and game theory etc.
reviews.comment_teaching: To be honest, her lecture is a bit boring. She will ask questions in the lecture and engage you to think more about the problem. You can skip all her lecture before midterm as materials were covered in DSE syllabus. However, it is better for you go to the tutorials as TA can help you fully understand the course materials and give you some hint for the final exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
Two schemes in total. The only difference between the two schemes is that one counts all 5 quizzes and one only counts 3. Since i missed the last quiz, I used scheme 2.

Problem Set: Full (8%)
Quizzes: 59/60 (24%)
All quizzes are open book and in MC format. They are all basic questions therefore the mean is extremely high. Just remember not to miss any quiz as it is much easier when compared to the final.
Final: 133/180 (68%)
Final was much harder than the quiz. Make sure you understand fully the course materials before the exam. Topics in the long questions are mainly the ones NOT COVERED in HKDSE syllabus. Lastly, never miss any tutorials. Part of the hardest question in the finals was covered in the tutorials.

Final Grade: A-
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is light. Only some problem set over the term and all you need to do is submit a blank paper. It will not be marked. For quiz, there are 5 quizzes over the term and workload is bearable. Make sure you understand all the course materials thoroughly before the quiz and you will be fine in final.

reviews.author: gazelle
reviews.comment_content: Content is 60% similar to DSE Economics. If you got ≥ level 4 in Economics, you should master the course materials with no big deal and get a B grade at least. Topics like PPF, demand and supply, elasticity, government intervention and externality are not difficult to understand. Later, perplexing stuff like budget line, indifference curve, perfect competition, monopoly, and game theory will be introduced. You need to understand the logic behind thoroughly thereafter because reciting everything won't help anymore.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Ding Fei's lecture is as boring as hell. You have to really pay attention to what she is talking about lest you can't resist but fall into sleep. In terms of the lecture materials, I would say they are not well-designed because they are too brief. Even the iPRS problems are far too simple compared to those in quizzes and final exam! To fully understand the concepts taught in lecture, you must carefully read through the textbook and make some notes on that.

My tutor is Jason Cheung, a fresh graduate from HKUST Economics. Attending his tutorial is far more effective than going to lecture. You can either listen to an organised summary of the topic or clarify your confusions by addressing to him face-to-face.
reviews.comment_grading:
My score

Problem sets (8 in total)  80/80  (mean 74.1/80)
Quizzes (5 in total)  82/100  (mean 82.9/100)
Final exam  120/180  (mean 102.76/180, sd 29.43)

Total score  75.47/100  (mean 70.26/100)
(Scheme 1 -- 52% final exam + 40% all 5 quizzes + 8% problem sets)

Final grade: B


I flunked out in one of the quiz (greatly below mean!!!) because I used the wrong way for studying. Even though I got 18/20 for most quizzes thereafter, eventually I could only get the total quiz result close to the mean score. For the final exam, the TAs marked the paper more vigorously than I expect. Even if you express the same meaning but without the key words they want, you would end up losing some points or even get a 0 score!!! My result of final exam was slightly lower than my expectation because of that. I am a little bit disappointed for not getting a B+ (I guess a ~80% is needed for a B+). Though, learning Economics is great!
reviews.comment_workload: This is only an introductory Economics course without vigorous Maths proofs. Only graphical illustrations and simple Maths representations are required. Without perplexing Maths (like multivariable calculus, econometrics......), workload should not be huge -- even people not sensitive to figures (who flunked out in Accounting course like me) should perform satisfactorily in this course. What you need to do before final exam is to summarize all graphs and concepts once, then try to express in words the logic behind and see how concepts and topics could be connected together. Don't forget to review the quizzes and the practice problems provided on Canvas as well.

reviews.author: Blaw God
reviews.comment_content: The content is about advanced DSE microeconomics. The first few weeks are about PPF and demand and supply (elasticity and tax), which would be easy if you study E2 in DSE and are familiar with DSE content. Afterwards, lessons need to be attended to learn advanced firm production. Utility, indifference curve, monopoly, oligopoly and game theory is new to us. It would be interesting if you enjoy economics.
reviews.comment_teaching: Her teaching is quite good. The pace is satisfactory, and she would ask us questions quite often in the lesson. Feel free to ask her questions after the lesson as she is nice, patient to answer you questions. Tutorial is complementary to her lectures. HECTOR CHENG my tutor is super great, who prepares his own tutorial notes every tutorial. The quiz and final review is really the key point to the quiz and exam. Personally speaking, his concept explanation is much clearer than FEI DING. Cantonese can be used to ask him question also.
reviews.comment_grading:
Scheme 1
Problem Sets 8%
Quizzes (8% each) All five: 40%
Final Exam (cumulative) 52%

Scheme 2
Problem Sets 8%
Quizzes (8% each) Best three: 24%
Final Exam (cumulative) 68%

I use scheme 2 because I miss one quiz.
My score:
8%
23.2% (19 or 20/20 for each quiz, mean for quiz is 16/17)
Final: 155/180 (Mean=102.76 S.d.=29.43)

89.76% finally, getting an A.
Fair grading
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is light. There are five mc quiz in total, testing 2 chapters each, which are quite easy.
8 problem sets in total, which you can just submit a blank word file to get one mark.

However, the final exam (cumulative) is undoubtedly difficult, consisting 1/3 mc and 2/3 long questions. The mc is much harder than the quiz. The long questions testing all chapters are complicated, so enough revision had to be done.

reviews.author: holam
reviews.title: ECON 2113
reviews.comment_content: Only some of them are covered in DSE. Most of the topics tested in the final exam are new topics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Lecture itself is not useful. The only useful part is you will figure out important points that will be tested in exam.
Tutorial itself is also not useful. But you should appear in order to take the tutorial note which will not have e-copy in Canvas.
Tutorials will be tested in exam.
Please note that you NEED NOT attend the tutorial assigned to you. Attend anyone that you think he is useful.
reviews.comment_grading:
Very good.
In the first lesson, the professor has already declared that she will give 20% to A range.
8% is for 8 assignment.
5 quizzes are given(20 MC each) and each of them is 8%(scheme 1).
Quiz are easy. Mean is 85%
You can skip two of them and transfer the proportion to final exam(scheme 2).
Basically, the grade wholly depends on the final exam.
In fact, I finish all quiz but eventually still use Scheme 2.
Focus on final exam. Focus on drawing graphs, each graph worths 6-10 points but words only 2-3 points

Marks: HW full
Quiz: 20 18 18 16 15
Final Exam: 165/180 mean = 98
Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
No attendance required
Very little workload. NO mid-term.
But the quiz time is rubbish. 4 of them is after 9pm and 1 is held 9am in study break.
Just submit a blank sheet in all assignment.
Only focus on final exam is fine.

reviews.author: Beautyli
reviews.comment_content: Content is not very hard. Most things have already been covered in Econ HKDSE. The new content introduced it easy to follow since HKDSE provides you a good foundation. As long as you listen carefully to professors' instruction, you can understand everything easily
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching is a bit boring, teacher will just read from powerpoint.
reviews.comment_grading: As long as  you finish all the task, and pass the mean, you can get a not bad grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is not very high, there are some games in some lessons
Attendance was voluntary, though there were some days where "games" were played and attendance was counted.

reviews.author: leonpjcheung06
reviews.title: Introductory course that helps you pick up things
reviews.comment_content: Although most of the content in this class are actually DSE topics, there are a few exceptions. For those familiar topics that we already know, we can go further and learn more advanced knowledge on certain topics.
reviews.comment_teaching: The lecture is actually boring. The professor didn't really skip much even she knew you have learnt those topics in Secondary School. And her voice would make you feel sleepy.
reviews.comment_grading:
Scoring a mean may give you a B. But personally I got an A+.
Just make sure you attend at least one mid term and the final
reviews.comment_workload:
Although there are homework requirements, you can actually ignore it. The professor won't check your work, you receive marks once you have it handed in. So you can hand in a blank word file and receive full marks.
But exercising is for you own good.

reviews.author: Doug Stamper
reviews.title: 肯上堂同勤力會靚grade
reviews.comment_content:
TL;DR同中學差唔多，撈埋啲野同多啲野

多左啲乜?
Game theory
呢個係教授既至愛，皆因佢做研究都係做呢樣，咁教乜呢?
1. 囚徒困境
2. game tree of sequential or simultaneous game
3. 點將game theory同oligopoly串連
Monopoly
如果你中學DSE上，老師應該有叫你跳左課好多圖、曲線同橫線既野，monopoly就似啦
簡單啲講，就係講monopoly
1. average variable cost
2. marginal cost
等等
Indifference curve
中學同你講demand curve係marginal benefit同willingness to pay既合體，無錯，不過唔係全部，咁indifference curve就補翻呢啲野.
簡單啲講，肯背野OK
呢個同教授有關
teaching講
reviews.comment_teaching:
優點係個人唔差，肯搞下笑，肯落堂答問題，你以為呢啲野係基本?上多啲course你就知唔係必然
跟住落黎都唔知優定缺
啫係佢好重視學生明唔明個邏輯，所以上堂解好詳細，呢個無問題
不過考試都正係期望你背到個邏輯就當你係識用呢下有啲問題
好聽啲講係好grade，因為佢考試啲問題同assignment啲問題一樣，而佢係會出到assignment幾難，但考試就大致相同
又係個句，好聽就係好grade la
第二樣就係佢好重視人上堂
咁佢就唔take attendance
不過緊要野都一定上堂先講
例如Midterm答案，個陣啲人midterm大炒，佢講明會final出翻相同野，仲講明個個答案正係上堂先講，絕對唔擺上canvas
所以就，令到想好grade要勤力加上堂....
其實就典型中學模式....
reviews.comment_grading:
我就算係outlier既
midterm & final above 2.5 sd
3/4份功課滿分.
咁就梗係A+啦

不過聽啲B既話靚grade，好似話踩mean都b range，咁自己諗啦
reviews.comment_workload:
毒撚會好辛苦
因為我就每份assignment都自己做，所以做到隻狗咁
不過除左assignment都無乜特別...

reviews.author: alexchw
reviews.comment_content:
It is quite easy to follow as most of the content are similar to the content of HKDSE Economics, except the part of Game Theory. If you don't understand the part of the Game theory, you may probably involve in the trouble...

So B for content.
reviews.comment_teaching:
It is no denying that she has enthusiasm to her teaching, but her voice is quite terrible as I think most of the students felt asleep during her lessons, which is sad. Besides, although she did spend time on answering the question of students through Email or after lecture, she just read the ppt during lecture and could not hold the time well.

So I can only give a C :(
reviews.comment_grading:
The grade is quite good. I get B+ finally even I have just attended 50% of lecture. There are two plan of counting your grade.

Plan A
5% Canvas assignment (Actually you can hand in your selfie, she will not check, so she gave you 5% free!)
10% Mid-term 1 ( with 40-45 MC, quite easy and mean should be around 85-88%while the mean in 2017-18 Fall is 87.75)
20% Mid-term 2 (also with 40-45MC, more difficult and mean is 75%)
65% Final (with 45-50 mc and some long q)

Plan B
5% canvas assignment
30% Mid-term
65% Final

You can choose whether to have 1or 2 midterm!!

Quite easy to get C range as I have a friend who got 46/200 in final, but he could be able to get a C. So the grade I think is good, A for grading!!!
reviews.comment_workload: good point is no attendance requirement. But you'd better to have revision through ppt in order to get better score in mid-term or final.

reviews.author: Bubblebot
reviews.comment_content:
Contents very similar to IB HL Econ.
Basics of Microeconomics
-supply and demand
-specialization
-Elasticity (HL calculations included)
-Theory of the firms (HL)
-Game theory (quite in depth so be careful)

If you have done HL Econ before, it will be pretty easy. If you have don SL Econ, reading IB textbooks really helps. The ppt made by professors usually sucks (i think). Also the recommended textbook isn't really beginner friendly.

Overall, almost all HL econ micro contents in one semester XD
reviews.comment_teaching:
She speaks decent English but it is hard to follow what is going on in the lecture.

THE EXAM PAPERS HAVE SO MANY GRAMMATICAL MISTAKES!!! I got very annoyed taking the multiple choice questions because I did not understand some questions at all because of confusing sentence structures and grammatical errors. Super annoyed after the first midterm. Even the long-answer (short essay) questions are shit. You do not know what the question is asking for.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading for this course is pretty shit because of really small std. You have to score very high. There is no attendance so the only things you need to pay attention is the midterm and final. don't miss marks from missing problem sets.

Scored 7/7/6/7 In HL econ (p1,p2,p3,IA) and scored C+ lol The exam style is so different in hkust
reviews.comment_workload:
Workload is ok - 8 problem sets
you just need to hand it in on canvas on time. The questions were same as last semester so many people just copied. The problem sets are not really related to the final exam so do not take it as an exam practice. You have to study for the final separately because the exam question style is quite different from textbook questions.

reviews.comment_content: The topics are mostly covered in secondary school under DSE syllabus but each topic would be taught in depth.
reviews.comment_teaching: His lessons are ok in a sense that they are not exceptionally interesting but not boring as well. He mostly follows the powerpoint but sometimes add some more explanations. He also covered topics that he is interested in and wants to share (e.g. prisoner's dilemma).
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is quite good. He gave the maximum amount of A grade he could, which he said is about 20%. I got around 1 SD higher for both mid-term and final and got B+ at the end.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fair. He doesn't take attendance so you can skip lessons but I would recommend you to attend because his explanations are important in the tests. There are 3-4 homework assignments which is a bit time-consuming doing them alone but by forming groups they are manageable.

reviews.author: Tristan
reviews.title: 易讀易靚grade
reviews.comment_content: 大部分中學教嘅野，新教嗰啲睇下powerpoint就識，主要係教micro野，好少計數，唔洗特別背書，明佢個concept就得
reviews.comment_teaching: 我剩係上左頭幾堂之後走曬，不過睇得出佢教學好有熱誠,上堂都會間唔中用iprs,不過唔計分
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm全MC,final一半mc一半long q,你肯睇下lecture notes基本上就識，midterm1高一個sd,final高兩個sd但係midterm2高少過一個sd,最後A,好難A+
Midterm1:95/100
Midterm2:80/100
Final:170/200
Grade:A
reviews.comment_workload: 功課有做就滿分，最緊要有交功課，不過考final前最好睇番功課答案,仲有走堂嘅話要記住成日check canvas睇幾時要交功課

reviews.author: wyrlau
reviews.comment_content: Half of the syllabus are DSE stuffs so there should not be any difficulties in handling it, for the remaining half, do not rely on her teachng, watch youtube and you will understand those concepts.
reviews.comment_teaching: Her monotone voice makes the lecture more boring despite the content of the course. She will blank some of the pages of the powerpoint so in order to get the content of those few pages, you will have to attend the lecture.
reviews.comment_grading: The final exam by Ding Fei is infamous for its difficulty. You will never know how to do all of the questions so just try your best at midterms since it is in mc format. You can be able to score a full mark if you are careful enough.
reviews.comment_workload: There are two mid terms and one final for the course and two ways of grading which you can choose the method that benefits you the most. Other than that, 10 tasks will have to be done throughout the whole semester but you can simply hand in a blank page since they offer you marks whenever you hand in the homework.

reviews.author: UST商科仔
reviews.comment_content: Content is so far not that difficult as all of us who are registered in this course have studied Economics in our high school and got at least level 4 in HKDSE. However, pls be expected that the topics learnt are the same while the concepts taught are not as same as before. Just like oligopoly, it is all about game theory and a set of stupid theory.
reviews.comment_teaching:
His teaching is so far good! His Korean like English accent makes me laugh every day. (No negative means). He uses funny way and accent to teach Economics.

However, he kept skipping powerpoint in his lesson.
So far the record is skipping every 6 slides of ppt at once.

Also, he skipped too fast and thus he "taught" every thing before the last lesson. But the way he used the last lesson was teaching some year 3/4 information economics, which, according to his own words from mouth, wont be needed in the final exam. This is the ridiculous thing I found.
reviews.comment_grading:
I really hate him,

First, his mid-term and final consists of long essay typed questions only. It seems that finishing 2-3 Long Questions within 2 or 3 hours is not a matter. However, the way he graded our paper is matter. The total marks for both mid-term and final exam are also 200. In particular, 2 80-mark questions and 1 40-mark question. Normally, in his mindset, there is only total right or total wrong. So basically, you are either getting 80 or 0.  His asshole mindset is really shitty in that the mean of his mid-term is around 96 and 100 in final.

I really hate this stupid shithole.
reviews.comment_workload:
He gave two homework only, and the time given is sufficient.
Also, he allowed us to form team to hand in the hw, which is what I appreciated.I

reviews.author: messixo
reviews.title: 0 workload + leng grade :D
reviews.comment_content: i think around 60% of the content is covered by the HKDSE syllabus and the remaining is about drawing curves and calculations. You can check other reviews out to know what topics exactly will the course covers.
reviews.comment_teaching: She teaches in monotone and you will definitely find her lessons boring. My lesson is at 0900-1020 so it was indeed a torture for me. Hence, I think I only attended 40% or less of her lessons as I think it was not so meaningful to me when I would actually drop off during her lessons. But watch out, if you plan to skip lessons, I highly recommend you to purchase the textbook n order to facilitate your learning and remember to read her powerpoints before finals too cuz some are not covered by the textbook.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is undoubtedly great. I think I was only 1 SD above mean in finals and not even 1 SD in quizzes, but I got A eventually by self-learning. Though ppl say the finals would be very difficult, it was not as tough as ppl ever said given you revision is enough and throrough.
reviews.comment_workload: This is the best fit for people looking for no workloads. She doesnt take attendance first of all, a blank document can be submitted as assignment on canvas if you dont want to work on it, and her quizzes are in MC format, it wouldnt be difficult at all. Yet, remember to study hard for finals as there will be 50% MCs and 50% long questions. Good luck :)

reviews.author: Vita
reviews.title: Interesting course.
reviews.comment_content: Most content is covered in DSE econ, except Game Theory and some graphs.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very terrible voice. Fall asleep very time in her lesson. For me, reading textbook is far more interesting more having her lesson.
reviews.comment_grading: Fair. You can get a good mark if you really spend time on it. But remember final exam is MUCH MORE difficult than the midterm, review on thing as hard as you can imagine.
reviews.comment_workload: Very slight. Even if you hand in a blank paper in the Canvas, you can get a full mark if you hand in your homework in time. But you need to spend much more time on reviewing the book before final, cause the difficulty level of final is much higher than that of midterm and problem sets.

reviews.author: ustbba0
reviews.comment_content: The content is quite interesting and he covered most of the topics in the HKDSE, and some contents are taught in a more advanced way, he would teach some questions on the classes and if you pay attention to it, you may find it rewarding and may help you pass your miidterm and exam.
reviews.comment_teaching: You can always talk to him in person after the class is ended and ask for some questions about topics covered on the lecture notes and he would give some decent answer that help you to understand different topics. Some of his personal experience would be shared on his class occasionally during the class to make it not so boring.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is good, in the lecture just after the midterm, he told us that top 20% would get a range. There were only 1 mid term and 1 final, no MCQ and they are all in long questions, most of the questions are in similar types as those in the homework. Therefore, if you can deal with the homework by yourself then the midterm and the exam would be a piece of cake.

Finally i got A in this course with both midterm and final above 2 sd. No attendance would be taken and what you need to pay attention to would be those exams and homework.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is light. You have to submit homework in person during the class, you can finish it alone or form your own teams that is up to 5 people to finish it and submit it as a group work.
